We have in view several more years of continuing growth, falling unemployment, rising employment opportunities, rising household disposable income, higher profit margins for companies and growing exports.

PARA.TAB: Today's current account figures that have come out are, of course, the monthly figures for the month of July. The Statistician cautions people approaching these figures to see them for what they are—monthly figures that are subject to revision and which are volatile. The market forecast a figure in the range of $2.2 billion to $2.6 billion; they came in at $2.1 billion—a level below what the market forecast. TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President, as to relevance, the minister might have in fact said that the trend figures are $2 1/2 billion and only down one per cent. —Order! There is no point of order.

PARA.TAB: I was making the point that this month is the first decrease in the monthly trend estimate since December 1993. It is in line with our expectations—expectations that we have forecast—that the current account will trend down over the course of the current year. We do not necessarily expect that it will trend down in dollar terms but we do expect, as we have forecast, that it will trend down in percentage terms. I say that because the economy is growing—and growing quite strongly and sustainably. We will have a surplus without asset sales in the following economic year. We will ensure that we have a program for national savings brought about by our commitment—and this government's commitment alone—to national superannuation by generating a pool of national savings for investment in our economy and by lifting overall the level of national savings in this country. Of course, the government is pursuing ongoing micro-economic reform, the latest instalment of that being the introduction of competition policy, which we piloted past the states in the most recent quarter. We have also been able to implement effective labour market reform. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Minister, I understand that next week you will be attending the first ever joint meeting of trade ministers from ASEAN—the Association of South East Asian Nations—and CER, closer economic relations, trade ministers. In view of the unquestionable importance of trade and investment with ASEAN to Australia's economic future, could you advise of Australia's plans for this meeting and the possible outcomes?

—This is an important new stage in the ongoing process of positioning Australia in the centre of the economic growth that is going on in our region here in East Asia. It is part of the process of winning a future for Australia, economically and otherwise. The important thing to recognise about this meeting—important as it is—is that Australia did not have to beg for a place in this or barge in or push our way in. We were invited by ASEAN to participate in this; it was their initiative. As a result of the ongoing and concerted strategy of this government over the last several years, we have earnt our place at this table.

PARA.TAB: It is important that economic groupings like CER Australia-New Zealand, and AFTA in ASEAN start this level of dialogue because it is what is happening globally. Within the Americas, within Europe, and between Europe and the Americas, you find this growing dialogue as trade spills over not only national borders but also the borders of free trade areas. Trade will not be contained within artificial boundaries that we write, so we need to participate in this global operation. Therefore AFTA CER is a very important linkage.

I cannot, of course, pre-empt the meeting or prejudge its outcomes, but what we are looking for and what I am hopeful of is that the meeting will take AFTA CER cooperation forward in two ways. Firstly, we want to establish a close and strong pattern of dialogue with ASEAN on multilateral and regional issues where in future we might be able to develop a platform for greater cooperation which will make us much more effective within the WTO and other discussions—for example, on the relationship between the Americas and Europe and their respective free trade areas. Secondly, we are looking for a very concrete program of activities, very practical activities to expand opportunities for Australian exporters and workers by removing impediments to business, barriers in the way of Australians doing successful trade into ASEAN, and by providing tangible benefits to traders and workers in both AFTA and CER.

There are great complementarities that are being recognised more and more between our economies. I will be visiting a number of ASEAN countries before the Brunei meeting, and it is my intention to discuss these issues further. I should point out that one of the countries I will be visiting is Vietnam. Unlike the opposition, we do want to have dialogue with this very important trading partner for Australia. We will not refuse to talk to them. We will not boycott this growing market, where thousands of Australians are getting jobs in supplying goods into Vietnam. It is a very important market for us.

The Australian private sector wants us to be involved. They are—and would necessarily be—concerned about the prospect of a government that refuses to talk to its trading partner and then gives differing explanations about why it refuses to talk. Perhaps to question the recollections of those opposite is a bit unfair; perhaps their recollections are confused. Perhaps we should have a royal commission into why they do not have accurate recollections of why they did not meet Mr Do Muoi a few weeks ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will employ the counsel assisting.

—We can appoint a counsel assisting, but if Mr Howard wanted to give evidence we would not let him come. We would get everybody else to give evidence first and then we would not let him arrive. Perhaps that is what we should do—his recollection seems to be a little confused. This is an important meeting. Whatever you think about the state of affairs in Australia—whether you support some aspects of what we are doing or not—this sort of economic engagement that AFTA CER captures is essential to any view of Australia's economic future and any economic plan which can credibly ensure Australia's future prosperity. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Five years ago, the Martin inquiry into banking recommended the introduction of a basic banking product, and the banks did nothing then. Two months ago, the Prices Surveillance Authority asked banks to revisit the issue under the big threat of close monitoring if they did not. Now, after six years, the Treasurer has given the banks until 15 September to deliver something on the development of new products. How would the Treasurer define an adequate response from the banks to his ultimatum? What is he really going to do about it if he does not get it?
—This is a speculative question asking me what the Treasurer will do if the banks do not do something which I, the Treasurer and this government believe they should do.
—The Treasurer raised them.
—Let us see first whether they do it. We will then deal with failure if they do not.

PARA.TAB: Let me get this question in context. First of all, this government has introduced far more competition in the banking system of Australia. If any customer of a particular bank is dissatisfied with the services they get from that bank, the strong advice of this government is to shop around and find another bank that will deliver the services they want. I can illustrate the high degree of competitiveness by pointing to the field of home loans and household lending, where it is possible to get different products from different banks simply by shopping around intelligently between banks. It is a more competitive environment.

In the normal course the government would have left this situation to be dealt with by the market and by consumer sentiment moving away from a bank that is imposing higher charges than banks that impose lesser charges in order that they might attract more customers. We did commission a Prices Surveillance Authority inquiry into banking charges. We did that because we believed that we needed to survey this area. We believed that there was a need to improve the accountability of the banking system in imposing higher charges on their customers. That is why we commissioned the Prices Surveillance Authority's survey.

As an outcome of that report, a number of recommendations which go to state regulation and other areas of banking have, I believe, been complied with. In the federal area the question of some of these charges formed part of the recommendations of the inquiry and, as you know, the Treasurer has contacted in this case the Commonwealth Bank, because in particular we believe that the accounting fee of $2 per month for accounts with less than $500 in them is positive discrimination against low income earners and those who have low deposits in accounts in banks—positive discrimination. We believe that the Commonwealth Bank should remove that charge.

The Treasurer has put those views quite strongly, has written to the banks, and we believe that the banks should remove that charge. At the present time their response is forthcoming. We will give them a reasonable margin of time before we decide what to do. But we have said this is not an empty request, that, if it is not complied with, the option for the government is to regulate and enforce compliance. As someone who is a self-confessed long-term depositor with the Commonwealth Bank when it was in public ownership, I am somewhat distressed to see that my bank is imposing these charges. If it continues to do so, I will shift my account to some other bank and I would urge every other consumer of that bank's services to do the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, except for increases in banks' profits, what has really changed in the culture of the banking sector in the last couple of years that would give us confidence that they are really going to change their attitude this time? Secondly, you are not really serious about any form of re-regulation, are you? You spent 12 years deregulating. Are you going to admit, by some form of re-regulation, that it has failed?

—What we are absolutely serious about is creating a competitive climate in banks so that consumers are the beneficiaries. If we find that banking charges are being pumped up unfairly, if that is the case, and there is militant resistance to fair overtures from an independent inquiry like that of the Prices Surveillance Authority, the Treasurer has made it quite clear that an option for this government is to regulate. We are loath to do so because we believe the market should work here, but if there is no choice it is an option and the government will face it. We are very determined about that.

—My question is to Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to the recent launch by the tourism minister, Michael Lee, of a major campaign to promote tourism in Australia. Recent research shows that, within four or five years, tourism from Asian countries alone, excluding Japan, will bring more money into Australia than does farm produce. Given the increase in the importance of the tourism industry to our economy and the fact that we expect around 6.3 million tourists a year by the 2000 Olympics, what is the government doing to make visa issue as fast and uncomplicated as possible for international visitors?

—I thank Senator Jones for his continuing interest in this area. The industry he draws my attention to is one which is important for Australia. It is an industry which Michael Lee tells me generates export earnings of about $11 billion each year and employs some six per cent of the work force. It is also an industry which, as you rightly say, Senator Jones, is growing. In recent years we have seen growth in tourism, growth which is projected to grow even further and at a faster rate as we turn to the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: Such growth presents challenges for government and for my department and they are challenges that I think are being met extremely well. The starting point of the government is to achieve a system of hassle-free visa issue for tourists to Australia. To that extent we have issued a number of significant and imaginative initiatives to try to simplify and to speed up the process. An important one, which I think senators may remember, is one that was trialled just a little while ago in Japan but which has now been extended to other countries. That is the issue of visitor visas by reputable and well-established travel agents. Those arrangements which had been trialled some time ago have now been extended this year to travel agents or airlines in Singapore, the UK, Malaysia, South Korea, Hong Kong and Slovenia.

Michael Lee and I will be announcing today that the response in those countries to agency arrangements has been so encouraging that we will be expanding the system further still. By the end of this year we anticipate that we will have agency arrangements in at least 15 countries. Phase 2 begins in September and October when arrangements will be operating in Italy, Germany, Denmark, the Netherlands, France, North America, Indonesia and Tahiti. Further arrangements are also being put in the place. Later this year we anticipate that other centres in Europe, such as Greece, and South Africa will also have agency arrangements.

The system we are talking about is straightforward. Visitors in these countries lodge their visa applications with a selected agent who electronically transmits the details to the local migration office for a decision. A decision is normally obtained within 24 hours. The decision is relayed to the sponsoring agent who is then authorised to issue a visa. In London, for instance, the system is working so well that agents effectively advise of visa decisions within about 30 minutes.

There are checks on the system. If immigration officers need to check matters further they can go directly to the individual and therefore protect the individual's privacy. We also have checks in place and safeguards have been built into the new arrangements so that participating agencies do not have access to information held on our databases.

As well as this particular initiative, we have also been working on other schemes such as the nominated visitor scheme which is for business visitors. This scheme allows their nominee in Australia to facilitate the processing. For instance, persons travelling will not have to visit migration offices themselves. We are also in the process of implementing an on-the-spot visa system which will soon be operating at trade shows and conferences in Europe. The first one will be taking off in Bonn in the not to distant future.

We are using new technology to ensure that when people arrive in Australia their processing time is cut. At the moment it takes on average only 55 seconds to process individual arrivals. We anticipate that, with the new technology coming on line later this year, we can effectively halve that time.

Can I say to Senator Jones that all this is happening at a time when we are having success with respect to overstayers in Australia and the protection of Australia's borders. All these systems that we have in place facilitating entry are not detracting from the fact that we have had a massive fall in the number of overstayers from some two per cent of those coming into Australia in 1989 to some 0.2 per cent now. That is an improvement of 90 per cent over the five-year period. That is the direction the government wants to take in this area in anticipation of growth in the system. (Time expired)

Are you not simply claiming the bank robber's defence—that is the one where the bank robber, when asked about the robbery a few days later, says emphatically, `I didn't do it'; then two or three years later at the trial most of witnesses come along and say, `Oh, yes, the alleged bank robber did in fact do it'? Do you honestly believe that the bank robber should be acquitted simply because he says, `My memory was fresher and the other witnesses just have a different recollection'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter in issue here is not whether certain things happened and not whether certain things were said and not whether certain knowledge existed. The matter in issue is when certain things happened, in what sequence and when people knew what was the case. On matters of that kind, human memory when it is unsubstantiated, unreinforced, unevidenced by any contemporaneous documentary evidence is notoriously fallible.

PARA.TAB: That is why this whole enterprise is destined to be, and always has been from the outset, an exercise in weighing, judging and evaluating competing memories. That is all it has ever been. On the one hand you are weighing and evaluating the memories of those who are coming along three years after the event with the memories and the statements made on the public record in the parliament by Carmen Lawrence five days after the event. Can you tell us what role John Howard played in setting up the Marks Royal Commission?

I probably did raise the issue with John Howard, I can't remember specifically talking to John Howard, but I spoke to a wide range of people . . . Well, as I said, I can't even recall discussing the matter with John Howard, but I'm not saying that I didn't.

That was four months ago. He said, `I can't even recall discussing the matter with him, but I'm not saying I didn't.' Again, he said, `I can't even recall having discussed the matter with John Howard, but I'm not saying I didn't because I discussed it with a wide range of people.' The journalist then asked, `So you can't remember a conversation you had with John Howard earlier this year?' Richard Court said, `No, I can't.'

PARA.TAB: Who can remember what your lot cannot remember? We are prepared to accept it at face value. I am not sure why we should accept it, given what Dr Wooldridge had to say when he said on the public record in April this year that the federal opposition was liaising with the state government as to the best way of setting up the inquiry. There is a bit of other evidence around out of the mouths of the babes and the innocents on your front bench saying, `Yes, we're up to our eyeballs in discussing this.'

We are prepared to accept the legitimacy of Mr Richard Court's answer that he cannot remember because that is the truth of the matter; often people cannot remember those things. All we ask is that there be no selectivity, no hypocrisy, no nonsense of the kind you are espousing on this particular instance.

It is a little bit mysterious that people cannot remember things as significant as this happening just four months ago. It is a little bit mysterious that people should have different recollections of something that happened the very same day, as was the case with Mr Downer and the Vietnamese ambassador. It is much more understandable that people should have different recollections three years after the event. Nonetheless, we will accept the legitimacy of these excuses. You should accept them too and understand that that is the way human memory works, and do not go on with this nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht, in his role as minister responsible for the national space program. I have seen claims that a program of American National Aeronautics and Space Administration, commonly known as NASA, for the launch of a number of rockets from Woomera was up in the air. Can the minister advise whether those claims are correct? If they are not correct, what space related activity is in prospect for Woomera?
—Bring it down to earth, Chris.

—As Senator McKiernan says, I will try to bring this down to earth with some true facts about what is going on. There was speculation in the press a few days ago that there was some doubt about this NASA program. I inform the Senate that last Friday I received a letter from Mr Ted Ankrum, who is the NASA senior representative in Australia, confirming arrangements for this program. In his letter, Mr Ankrum advises `the program is going ahead, but with a slip of seven days from the previous schedule'. He also advised me that the rockets are now en route to Australia and the first of the NASA personnel involved in the program are scheduled to arrive in Woomera on 8 September.

PARA.TAB: Woomera will be the launching facility for the program of seven launches for scientific purposes. The rocket is a Black Brandt IX, a two-stage rocket which are each about 13 metres long, including the payload. The launches will put a payload up between 200 to 500 kilometres, depending on the payload and the elevation. They will be conducted in October and November this year. By October, we could have between 80 to 100 people from NASA based in Woomera for that two-month period for this program. Each of the launches will carry out a range of scientific research programs for a number of universities in America as the southern hemisphere is the most effective place for these launches to take place.

Woomera is an excellent site for space related activities, as the Japanese have also recognised. It is the preferred site for the Alflex experiment which are flight trials of a one-third model of the proposed Hope reusable space vehicle.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was proposed three years ago.

—I am saying this, Senator Panizza, because one of your colleagues was casting great doubt on this program and suggested that it would not take place. It will be taking place. The trials will take place between February and April next year. They are part of an ongoing program that we have with the Japanese space agency as a result of discussions that I have had in Japan with the chairman of its space agency.

PARA.TAB: The only issue to be resolved is the issue of liability, and that is now being negotiated. This very week there are officials from the Japanese space agency in Australia talking to officials of the Australian Space Office to finalise the liability issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should have been fixed up months ago.

—I believe even Senator Chapman will want to make sure that the Australian public and Australian interests were properly protected if there was the remotest chance of something going wrong. We are negotiating to make sure that liability is with the Japanese who want to use Woomera. I am sure we will have a successful outcome in those discussions. I suggest to Senator Chapman that, when both the American and the Japanese experiments take place, he is quite welcome to come to Woomera and observe the result of this government's policy in reactivating Woomera as a space facility in Australia.

—My question is directed to Senator Gareth Evans representing the Prime Minister. Are you aware that medical dictionaries describe a condition called mythomania whereby a person avoids conflict by lying and then believes the lie to avoid further stress? What government funding is available for the treatment of this condition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is anyone with that condition at the moment it must be Richard Court in Western Australia because when confronted with the stress of a straightforward journalist's question today—

PARA.TAB: But Senator Robert Ray was wrong earlier on when he said that that is the only evidence I had of that. That is totally untrue. What about the evidence of Alexander Downer coming out of his meeting with the Vietnamese ambassador—not four months after the event, but less than four hours after the event—and obviously forgetting what had been said at the meeting, forgetting that nobody had raised human rights, but forgetting to get that right when he put out his press release and having to be bailed out by his leader drawing attention to the phenomenon of mythomania as experienced by his shadow minister and having to say that obviously Alexander Downer was a case here, because people can come out of meetings `with different understanding'?

It is a phenomenon that is alive and well in the opposition benches of this country. If I were you, Dr Herron, I would be getting out my prescription book and looking around for all the other candidates on your side who have this disease.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Schacht and relates to the tragic situation of youth unemployment in Australia at the moment of 28.2 per cent—22,600 young long-term unemployed people. I refer to the statement made by Professor Peter Dwyer of Melbourne University that `the federal government policies are keeping Australia's young adults in a limbo land of education and training in the mythical expectation that their employment future is secure'. I ask, as did Professor Dwyer: what is the government's forecast for youth employment in the year 2001 when the policy is fully in place? Will the government at last concede—(Time expired)
—I am not aware of having seen the remarks of Professor Dwyer from Melbourne. They have not been brought to my attention, Senator Harradine.
—The Australian conference is on now in Adelaide.

—The conference is on at the moment. I attended the welcoming function on Sunday night for that conference and Mr Crean, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, officially opened the conference on Monday, and the Department of Employment, Education and Training, DEET, is a major sponsor of that conference, so I think it is quite clear that we, as a government, have recognised the value of that conference.

PARA.TAB: I also want to pay a tribute to the people who organised it, particularly from the northern suburbs of Adelaide, where there is a level of youth unemployment that is unacceptable, which the government has made clear. That is why we are sponsoring this conference, which has over 400 people attending—from not just around Australia, but from overseas—and giving papers. The emphasis is on attracting young people in their late teens and early-20s who are experiencing, obviously, unemployment and have had that experience to contribute their ideas. On Sunday night, Senator Harradine, I had a long conversation with several of those young people as they put their views about the social impact of long-term youth unemployment. They did it in a very articulate way, which I acknowledge.

You implied in your remarks, quoting Professor Dwyer, which remarks I have not seen, that we are not interested in or we are not doing enough for youth unemployment. I want to draw your attention to the major commitment this government has made in the Working Nation statement of last year where, over a period of four years, we will be spending around $4 billion to $5 billion of funding on top of what we have already committed and particularly aiming it at getting long-term young unemployed people back into jobs through better training, through case management arrangements and so on.

Already, in the last year, there has been over 200,000 new jobs created in Australia; there has been a substantial reduction in long-term unemployment; and there has been a reduction in youth unemployment. I believe that the support this government has given through Working Nation to tackle long-term unemployment, including youth unemployment, is an example that we can all be proud of. Certainly, this government is,but we are not going to rest on our laurels. We acknowledge that youth unemployment is a major issue. No government, including this one, will walk away from the fact that it is still unacceptably high. But we are dealing with it. We would just ask people to compare our policies with the non-existent policies of those opposite for dealing with youth unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry but I have to ask this supplementary because my question was not answered. Could the minister please provide, as requested by Professor Dwyer, the government's forecast for youth employment in the year 2001 when your program will have been completed? I also draw the attention of this minister to the fact, and I would ask this minister to address the point, that the missing link in your thinking appears to be your failure to concede that there are more people in or seeking paid work than there are jobs available and that you need to do something to give people the choice to engage in socially constructive alternatives? Please can that be considered, because I think that may be the missing link.

—I will refer the first part of the supplementary question to Mr Crean and bring back to Senator Harradine the figures on the target for youth employment in the year 2001. Senator Harradine may disagree with government policy in this area, but the whole thrust of our economic restructuring in Australia over the last decade is to make Australia an internationally competitive economy by creating good jobs, high value added jobs, particularly for our young people. I think there is more than enough evidence to show that we are having more than some success in that area. Not to say that we are satisfied with what we have achieved so far in that there is still a need for more jobs, particularly for young people. I will provide Senator Harradine with further information in that area after I consult with the minister, Mr Crean.

—My question is to Senator Bolkus representing the minister for local government. Can the minister please explain why federal tax revenues have increased by 49 per cent in real terms since this government came to office in 1983; yet, for the next financial year, financial support for local government will be three per cent less in real terms than it was 12 years ago? Why has the government chosen to reduce general purpose funding for local government from one per cent of total federal tax revenue in 1983 to only 0.67 per cent in 1995-96? Why has the government inflicted such financial hardship on local government by not passing on the massive increases in revenue which it has imposed on the Australian taxpayer?

—This question actually raises some selective statistics from recent history to build up a case. My experience is never to rely on such selectivity but to go to the source for more comprehensive information, and I will do that. I will refer this question to the relevant minister. In doing so, I would also ask Senator Calvert to note that, in terms of federal tax revenues, it is undisputed that we actually have very low rates of tax revenues at the moment, historically very low. That ought to be taken into account.

PARA.TAB: In terms of recognition of local government, it should also be placed on the record that this government's commitment to local government funding has been diverse, varied and extensive—

TALK.START.PARA: —And getting much less.
—not only in terms of funding but also, as Senator Ray quite rightly put on the record a few seconds ago, the fact that we—
—Put up your figures now. Put them on the table now. How much?
—He is asking you how much you would spend.
—Order! Address your answer to the chair.

—We have also recognised the role for local government, a role that we would be quite keen to see implanted in the constitution. But, for some reason, you oppose that constitutional measure. I also say to Senator Calvert that, in raising issues like this, it would be quite important to get your story straight over there. Maybe, after discussions between you and the shadow spokesperson, you would be able to inform the Senate and the Australian public better as to what your position is.

PARA.TAB: On the one hand we do have an extensive record and commitment by this government but, on the other hand, from Senator Ian Macdonald we have, published and publicised, a wish list with a rider saying, `We can offer the mugs everything; they might believe it, but we don't have to deliver until after the election'. That is your approach to local government; that is your approach to the regions—fantasy promised before the election, but silly enough to leave a rider in there saying, `The beauty about this is that we can promise everything but don't have to deliver anything'. That is your commitment to local government—much different to ours.

It may be more appropriate, senator, in the future when you raise issues like these, if you discuss them with your side of the parliament so that you do not make yourself look like a goose when you raise matters demanding more funding, when your own side has absolutely no intention of meeting the sorts of demands you place on us and, at the same time, when your own side does not have any particular commitment at all in this particular area. I will go back to the minister; I will get you the precise record and the precise information. In the process, let me just suggest to you that a bit of honesty and commitment from your side in this matter might also enhance the debate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a question addressed to Senator Schacht representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer the minister to the comments of Melbourne University's vice-chancellor elect, Professor Alan Gilbert, who is reported in today's Australian as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: To maintain the quality and breadth of their activities, universities may have to proceed further down the road of partial privatisation, which most are already treading hesitatingly.

I ask: which government policies have led to the situation where a vice-chancellor thinks that that is an appropriate thing to say? Why has the government abandoned its responsibility to properly provide the Australian community with education opportunities to fully develop the skills and talents of our young people? When will the government admit that it has failed to properly invest in the education of Australians?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, first of all, I thank Senator Bell for giving us some indication that he wanted to raise this issue today in question time. As a result, I have been able to get some information. I make it very clear the government policy is and will remain that compulsory, up-front tuition fees are not to be charged to Australian students undertaking undergraduate programs at publicly-funded universities. The higher education contribution scheme is a mechanism by which these students contribute to the cost of their tuition.

PARA.TAB: There have been no cuts to higher education, nor is there a widening gap in the funding of higher education between 1989 and 1996. Between 1989 and 1996 total Commonwealth funding for the sector has risen in constant prices from $3.8 billion in 1989 to $5.25 billion, and funded places have increased from 322,000 to 417,000. In 1996 the government will provide $12,575 for each full-time equivalent student place—almost seven per cent more than the equivalent rate in 1989. The government has given universities the flexibility to charge fees for postgraduate students, overseas students and students in non-award courses. They may also diversify their income sources by providing services to business, through research and consulting, joint commercial ventures and commercial arms.

Professor Gilbert's argument that increased enrolments are threatening the quality of higher education misses the point. Over the last few years cut-off scores in some courses have gone down, reflecting changing patterns of demand for higher education. The Commonwealth's successful campaign to encourage year 12 students to consider TAFE and Australia's economic recovery have reduced the level of unmet demand for higher education.

As measured by Professor Gilbert's own representative body, the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee, these movements in demand are reflected in university cut-off scores, a process which does not reflect the quality of higher education. The government has actively sought to bring students who would not otherwise have gone to university into the higher education system. Indeed, it would have been impossible and undesirable for cut-off scores to remain constant given the government's objectives of producing a larger and more diverse higher education system. Is Professor Gilbert advocating turning back the clock 30 or 40 years to a time when few Australians had the opportunity to go to higher education? In the late 1940s only two per cent of 17- to 22-year-olds went to university. The ratio is now more than 15 times that figure.

Once upon a time the final years of primary schools catered for an elite. No-one would argue that the 100 per cent retention rate in primary schools has led to a decline in the quality of our school education system. Professor Gilbert himself advocated at the University of Tasmania an expansion of that university's undergraduate enrolments, presumably not to decrease the quality of its graduates. Professor Gilbert's point about the quality of graduates is an entirely different matter. The quality of graduates depends not only on the academic ability of students who enter higher education but also on the educational experiences that higher education institutions offer to their students. It is the education environment of Australia's universities which will determine whether they are attractive to international students.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Vanstone this day, relating to ministerial responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of issues at stake in relation to this matter which need to be addressed and addressed most forcefully. Quite clearly the situation is that, when you have a royal commission, there is an inquiry into certain allegations and comments made. It is therefore highly appropriate that the person at the centre of those allegations and comments be called toward the very end so that person has the opportunity to address each and every allegation and comment made by all the various witnesses that have gone before. If Senator Evans really believes that Dr Lawrence should have been the first witness, she would have needed to come back each and every time to respond to each and every single witness that may have given evidence about some other matter which she did not address in her first appearance before the royal commission. As Senator Evans's comments clearly indicate, much as the Labor government would have liked to have moved Senator Evans out of the Senate, it could not afford to appoint him to the High Court because his understanding of these procedures is so abysmally poor.

PARA.TAB: The question of integrity was raised and whether or not Carmen Lawrence had an accurate recollection of what occurred. The Herald-Sun told us yesterday what the people in Victoria thought. Seeing that Dr Lawrence and the government are so anxious to quote polls about this situation, I point out that 90 per cent of the respondents did not believe Carmen Lawrence. In her own electorate, the vote is two to one against Carmen Lawrence on whether or not she is to be believed. There are some important things in life that absolutely stick in your mind. A great Australian, John McInnes, has a very good recollection of what happened on 15 July 1967. It was the day that he sacked Paul Keating. As he says:
We had complaints about him all the time. He was also unmanageable, elusive . . .

SPEECH.PARA: John McInnes goes on about the reasons Paul Keating was dismissed from I think the one and only job that he had in private enterprise.

PARA.TAB: There are certain matters that people recall because of the import of the moment. It is quite clear to date, given the evidence that is before the commission—I only put it as strongly as that; the evidence that is currently before the commission—there is a shadow over the minister for health. She may well come back with her version of events which are quite proper and which may completely exonerate her. That may well be the case. But the situation is that as Senator Evans said when he made that very tacky attack on Senator Vanstone's sister-in-law: `You have to be beyond reproach.' It was absolutely pathetic and disgraceful and not at all becoming of somebody who likes to trot the world stage as a master diplomat and somebody who lusts after the position of Secretary-General to the United Nations. I would have thought he would have to clean up his act a bit before he could lay claim to such a job.

There is now a shadow over the minister for health; clearly there is. As a result, it would be appropriate for her to stand aside during the inquiry and allow the inquiry to take its course. It really is amazing to see the government attack the way the commission is being run, saying that the person who is required to answer all these allegations ought to be the first witness. When would she then have the opportunity to respond to all the other ministers and all her staff members? It would be an absolute nonsense—a procedural nightmare.

Senator Evans as a QC ought to know better. What he is trying to do is mislead the people of Australia by these comments, knowing full well that procedural fairness demands that every single witness who may say something adverse to Dr Lawrence says it before Dr Lawrence is required to give her version of events. That is the only fair and proper way to conduct the matter. That is the way Mr Marks has chosen to do it. To try to attack the royal commission is highly inappropriate. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that Senator Gareth Evans might like to respond. Perhaps he feels he has done enough damage to the public standing today. What he did in the Senate today was stoop to a new low. What he did in here today, obviously in an effort to protect Minister Lawrence, was decide that the best tactic was to attack the credibility of the commission itself and the credibility of the royal commissioner.
—How low is the royal commission? One politician sets up a royal commission to get another politician.

—Minister Collins interjects, `How low is the royal commission?' That is typical of his attitude. Not only does Senator Evans seek to attack the royal commissioner, but he decides to take a swipe at counsel assisting the commission as well. He has the nerve to come in here and try to dictate to counsel the order in which counsel should be calling the witnesses. If it is not in the order that Senator Evans says is the appropriate order, then counsel is acting improperly; counsel is politically motivated. What a new low for a Leader of the Government in the Senate to reach!
—A would-be High Court judge, at that.

—He will never be a High Court judge. This is a legitimate royal commission, set up by the government of Western Australia to look at the events leading to the presentation of a particular petition and the role various ministers and others took in that decision-making process. It was absolutely legitimate. I concede that the government can come along and attack motives. That is fair in the business of politics; but to go to the next step after the commission has been legitimately set up—the minister and his government are concerned about the potential of an adverse finding against Minister Lawrence—and attack the credibility of the royal commission and the counsel assisting the royal commission is, as I said, a new low.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to look at the attitude of this government to the royal commission. In an effort to protect Minister Lawrence, what did they first do? They sought to close down the commission. They used taxpayers' money in an attempt before the court to have the commission closed, in order that Minister Lawrence would never have to appear before the commission and in order that the truth would not be established.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now she wants to rush in.

—That is the inconsistency. When that does not work, she then dictates—it had no relationship to her role as a federal minister, but that did not stop this government spending taxpayers' money on it; it was at taxpayers' expense—that she wants certain witnesses cross-examined before she gives evidence. At the same time, she comes out and condemns the commission for not allowing her to give evidence now. She wants it both ways. Minister Evans comes into the Senate and condemns counsel assisting the royal commission for not complying with that request, which it is impossible to comply with.

PARA.TAB: What is this government seeking to do other than protect its minister and avoid the truth? We have heard a nonsense argument from Senator Evans day after day that because, he says, Minister Lawrence was the first to deny certain events, that should be believed over the evidence of a whole series of other witnesses. Has he considered the position that that denial placed her former colleagues in? Has he considered that it is very difficult for her former colleagues to come out subsequently and say something that contradicts her?

In fact, what has happened, in these circumstances of a royal commission when the public, through that process, is seeking the truth, is that these witnesses have come out and put the different position. But he says that their evidence should not be given the same credit as hers because she was the first to deny it. That, Minister, does not prove anything at all.

An enormous weight of evidence is building up—with not just a different recollection. This is not an issue of the recollection of events. Here we have her own deputy coming to her the day afterwards and saying that he is so upset about her conduct that he wished to resign. Senator Gareth Evans says, `We can quite understand why Minister Lawrence would forget that occurring.' What nonsense! How unreal! How can you realistically expect the Australian public to accept that?

But Minister Lawrence will now have her day before the commission. She will have her day to put her case, and the commissioner will have the responsibility of weighing the evidence that has been put before him by a whole range of witnesses and bringing down a finding of where he believes the truth lies. I suppose the only pleasing thing we finally got out of Senator Gareth Evans today was that if it is demonstrated that she lied the logical consequences must follow. That is very different from the attitude that this government has taken today. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many different ways of running cases—civil and criminal litigation—for the defence and many different ways of running a royal commission. But it is unusual, it is very odd, to say the very least, when the royal commission is an inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the lodging of a petition, not to seek very early on in the course of those proceedings evidence from the petitioner, Mr Halden. It is very odd not only not to seek evidence from the petitioner but also not to seek evidence from the person on whom the petitioner relied, Mr Easton, as to the substantive content of that petition.

PARA.TAB: Given, as everyone knows, that the primary target of the whole enterprise is Carmen Lawrence, the Premier of Western Australia at the time, and what she knew about the petition, whether she had advance knowledge of it and whether any of her conduct was improper—nobody denies that that is at the heart and soul of this whole enterprise—it is very odd, unusual, to say the least, not to be seeking evidence from her at a very early stage of the proceedings.

It is absolutely nonsensical to say, as Senator Abetz did, that under those circumstances these witnesses would have to be called back after every other witness to give a response. They would certainly, no doubt, need to be called back, and would want to be called back, at the end of the proceedings, including, in particular, Dr Lawrence, but also the petitioners, Halden and the other guy. All three of them could reasonably have been expected to be called at the beginning of the process and, to the extent that other things were said during the proceedings in evidence which might have been contradictory, it would then be perfectly appropriate, at the end of the proceedings, to recall Dr Lawrence and the petitioners to give further evidence on the basis of those inconsistencies.

That is the way these things are done, and it raises questions as to why they were not done in this instance. Maybe there are good answers to those questions but we have not heard them. What we have now on the record, as of yesterday, which is the reason I raised this today—until then the situation was ambiguous—is a clear and explicit refusal from the commission to respond affirmatively to a clear and explicit formal request from Dr Lawrence to give evidence sooner rather than later, not to wait till the middle of September but to come on and give evidence now.

Everyone knows why she would want to give evidence at this point in time. It is perfectly appropriate that she should make that request. It needs to be answered why that request was refused. If you are going to run a royal commission like this, tacky as it is, and you want to pretend that everything is above board, that the whole proceedings are impartial from go to whoa, then those proceedings should not only be impartial but also be seen to be impartial.

There is a very real question as to how impartial they could possibly be when someone who is not a bit player in the proceedings but absolutely central to the conduct of those proceedings, the counsel assisting the royal commission, is someone who is a close family relative of the shadow cabinet minister in the federal parliament who has an obvious axe to grind in this particular issue.

This, from start to finish, is a political ramp, it is a political royal commission and people who get caught up in it have to expect these sorts of questions to be asked and they should be prepared to answer these sorts of questions. They should be prepared to answer why we have a South Australian silk rather than a Western Australian silk appearing in this particular role. They have to expect to be asked what role they are playing in the conduct of the proceedings and what role they will play so far as the writing of the report is concerned. And they have to be expected to be asked, as I now ask Senator Vanstone to put on the public record and explain, whether there has been contact, discussion, dialogue, consultation between the two of them.

If you want to minimise, if you want to change the appearances, if you want to minimise the risk to the appearance of impartiality, Senator Vanstone—who is not in the chamber at the moment—can go some distance to answering this by coming in here and giving an assurance in the Senate that she has not discussed the subject matter of this commission with the royal commission. If she wants to answer this concern that I have raised about the impartiality and the appearance of impartiality, she can help to respond to that, she can help to answer that by coming in here and giving such an assurance—and I invite her to do just that. And, until she does it, she has to expect these sorts of questions to continue to be asked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I have always had some regard for Senator Gareth Evans and for his integrity, if nothing else. I think he is a hopeless minister, but I have always thought that he had some integrity.
—Coming from the chief sleaze of the Senate, that is cute.
—Senator Collins, I ask you to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.

—I don't take any notice of what Senator Collins says, Madam Deputy President, so it never worries me. Senator Collins would not understand some of the proprieties of the law. He attempted to become a lawyer and failed miserably; but he just doesn't understand those sorts of things.

PARA.TAB: As I say, I used to have some regard for Senator Evans, but this must be an all-time low that Senator Evans has sunk to. He attacks someone. I don't know Ms Vanstone who is involved in the commission. I understand that she is a leading member of the South Australian bar. TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Hill proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), after nearly 13 years of Labor Government, to give mainstream Australians confidence in their economic future.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I also thank the government for its indication that it would cooperate in bringing on this important issue, even if it disagrees with the content. There is probably no more important matter that the Senate could be debating today than the lack of economic confidence in the minds of most Australians concerned about their economic future. I guess their concern flows from the fact that, under this government, they experienced the worst recession that we have had in 60 years, the highest interest rate since the last war and the appalling spectacle of over one million Australians unemployed—all to be followed by what has been so aptly described as a recovery of five minutes of sunshine, a moment or two of hope that things were going to be better for the future.

PARA.TAB: Now what we find is a rapidly deteriorating public confidence. In a few months time, Australians will be asked to judge the performance of this government over the last nearly 13 years. What they will look back upon is a miserable economic legacy. They will look back upon wages and salaries, with living standards actually deteriorating in real terms. They will look back upon what we have had in terms of mass unemployment. Certainly, they will remember the brief glimmer of hope that they had in the early days of the recovery that things would be better.

Now they will reflect upon a whole series of economic results that suggest their future is far from bright. The last of those results is as current as today. What we had today was, for the 11th month in succession, a current account deficit exceeding $2 billion. The June-July current account deficit was in actual terms just over $2 1/2 billion, in seasonally adjusted terms just over $2 billion and in trend terms—which is perhaps the most important—still at a figure of $2 1/2 billion.

As I said, that is 11 months in a row with over $2 billion of deficit and one further month with the deficit just a fraction under $2 billion. July was the first time in 19 months, since December 1993, that the figure has not registered a deterioration. In other words, up until June we had had 18 consecutive months of deterioration. This is the recovery post the recession and post the time of misery.

On the trend figure, the improvement this month is only slight—about one per cent. When the final figures come out, there may still be a deterioration. So one month's slight improvement cannot disguise or conceal the deterioration that we have had over the past 12 months.

Regrettably, imports are still growing faster than exports. Imports in the 12 months to July grew by 18.5 per cent on the trend; exports, by 12.9 per cent on the trend. Within imports, consumption goods are growing faster than capital goods. Consumption goods in the 12 months to July grew by 15.6 per cent; capital goods in the 12 months to July grew by 12.7 per cent. The deficit on merchandise trade nearly doubled during the 12-month period—it rose by 84 per cent—and the deficit on services rose by 77 per cent. Depressing figures, I regret to say, but figures upon which this government will be judged.

In spite of the improvements in July, there are disconcerting features apparent in those numbers. Even though there was a marked improvement in the merchandise trade deficit during that month, within imports there was a nine per cent increase in consumption goods while capital goods fell by 15 per cent.

Madam Deputy President, this current account deficit is not new. This government has budgeted this year for a current account deficit of $27 billion. That is on top of last year's current account deficit of $27 billion, and is only marginally less than the 6.1 per cent that this country was running at, also when Mr Keating was pulling the levers, back in 1986. We all remember the warning that he issued at that time, that these figures could not continue without Australia in fact becoming a banana republic. So we have gone from 1986 to 1995, and the same figures are recurring. This government will now be pleased that no longer do we have the worst set of figures in all of the OECD; apparently, Australia is now the third highest. No longer can we say that our figures are even worse than Mexico's—but, regrettably, they are not much better. This is a result of excessive spending and insufficient savings and, of course, it must be seen against a rapid escalation in the rate of our foreign debt.

In 1983 the debt was, in net terms, $23 billion. It has now risen to some $163 billion. This is the legacy that this government will take to the next election: our external accounts running at a massive and continuing deficit with no real sign of any significant improvement at all in the trend, again approximately in the terms the government was presenting to the people back in 1986, and a foreign debt situation that has deteriorated so appallingly from some $23 billion to $163 billion. It is not surprising, in those circumstances, that so many Australians feel unsure and lacking in confidence about their economic future.

It all translates in due course into figures that affect Australians in their everyday lives. It translates into figures of high, and continuing high, interest rates—and a worry in fact that they will go higher. Despite the denials of this government, Australian interest rates, as a consequence of the economic policies of this government, are about the highest that can be found in the Western world. It is not surprising, therefore, that particularly small business finds it so difficult to compete in an international market when their interest rates are as high as any that occur in the Western world.

In fact, if you work off the prime bank rate—and I know the government will search for another figure—we are right up at the top of the table, equal with Italy, with the highest rates in the developed world. It is not just small business that suffers as interest rates go up, of course; it is home buyers and families as well. We have the very disturbing situation at the moment where families are struggling—struggling to pay high interest rates, and interest rates that are going higher as many are coming out of what has been referred to as a one-year holiday.

As a result of this government's inept economic management, people are actually seeing the value of their asset, their home, usually their principal asset, dropping. In those circumstances, not only when they have to find more to pay their interest bill each month but when they find their asset in some circumstances—and, regrettably, with an increasing occurrence—not exceeding the value of their debt, what they have had to borrow to buy the home, they become exceedingly worried about the future. So the picture, it seems, that this government will be taking to the Australian people at the next election will be one of rising interest rates because it is unable to manage the current account, and also, regrettably, one of rising inflation.

We were told that rising inflation would not occur, yet the underlying figures demonstrate, from the Reserve Bank's recent figures, that the government has failed in that regard. We had such eminent persons as Mr Phillips, the former Governor of the Reserve Bank, last week expressing his concern to the government. So we find inflation going up, interest rates going up, and the economic future for most Australians highly uncertain. There is very little doubt that they will take out their revenge on this government as a result of that economic failure.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, this is one in a row of opposition MPIs that we in this chamber have become used to. It is a matter of public importance placed on the agenda paper by the opposition to try to peddle the big lie about the Australian economy, to try to undermine what is still very strong confidence in the Australian economy, and to try to put in the minds of consumers that they have worries where worries do not exist.

PARA.TAB: Should any of my remarks be attacked, let me go to the concluding points of the last speaker, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill). The two issues he touched on were interest rates and inflation. He touched on them with the purpose of trying to massage anxiety in the electorate, to talk down the economy, to ignore the strength of the fundamentals of this economy, and to peddle dreariness and a lack of confidence as ways in which he believes he can talk down the strength of this government in the eyes of the electorate so as to try to somehow stumble to electoral victory on the back of, as I say, a big economic lie. I am sure when I conclude my speech that we will hear again from Senator Short who, in his dreary, stumbling manner, practises this art in this chamber as well.

Mr Acting Deputy President, there are two strong things that those listening to this broadcast should bear in mind. The first is that the fundamentals of this economy are indeed very strong. In world terms we are looking at an extremely healthy economy. The second thing that we should bear in mind about this speech is that the opposition approached this debate with a series of platitudes which they claim as policy. In fact, that policy is bankrupt, that policy is sterile. But that policy has one part of it which is creating massive anxiety in Australia, and rightly, and that is the industrial relations element of that policy. I will say more about that later.

On the point of national savings, let me not allow the comments of the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill, to pass when he talks about the need to accumulate a level of national savings. We have a scheme to do that, and it is working: national savings are abuilding. We have that through the surplus the budget will deliver in outgoing years. As well, we have it because of our national superannuation scheme and the funds that that will generate in the economy. That will create a medium-term level of national savings able to generate investment for Australia so that we, a country traditionally investment hungry, will be a country that is an investor in the world, not a country that seeks investment from the world. That is what our scheme is about.

But the opposition policy on superannuation is a policy that will kill superannuation in this country stone dead, and it will do it in a manner which will undercut any coherent national savings scheme. The opposition cannot speak with any credibility in any public fora anywhere in this country on superannuation or on national savings because their policy settings, as we know them to be, will deny Australians dignity in retirement and will also reduce the level of national savings capable of being generated under the policies that we have.

This MPI was created in anticipation of today's current account figures. It was created by the opposition's gloomy self-belief in the expectation that the figures would be worse than the market anticipated, or would be at the level that the market anticipated. Of course, the figures have come in today, delivered here by the Statistician, better than the market anticipated. We see that the July result was $431 million, or 17 per cent lower than the revised result of the previous month, and we see that the July outcome included the first decrease in the monthly trend estimate of the current account deficit since December 1993. With those results being returned, we see that the forecasts we have made about the direction of change in the economy are beginning to show through, at least in this first instalment of the figures, and that the trend is for further improvement because the trend line is in this direction for improvement. So the basis for this MPI has been somehow cut from underneath the opposition because the theory of gloom that they had generated in their own mind was not realised by the facts. Reality bit the opposition in these figures; the opposition did not exploit reality.

A lot has been said about our performance with respect to the OECD, and Senator Hill tries to make an art form of this. In 1994 in terms of real GDP Australia ranked as the third highest country in the OECD. We had the third highest growth rate of any country in the OECD according to the OECD Outlook publication No. 57. Of the 24 most advanced countries in the world, Australia in growth terms ranked at No. 3. In investment terms, real total gross fixed capital formation, in 1994 Australia was ranked of the 24 OECD countries as the third highest. In inflation with the GDP deflators, Australia was ranked of the 24 OECD countries as having the fourth lowest level of inflation. In growth in the labour force, Australia of the 24 OECD countries was rated as having the fourth highest growth in labour force participation in that period. In employment growth—in the ability to generate new jobs, offer hope, employment and better living standards for its citizens—of the 24 OECD countries Australia was ranked as equal second.

In general government outlays as a share of GDP—that is, in government expenditure—how does Australia rate in the world, given the rantings of the opposition? Among our peers we have the third lowest outlays of any government in the developed countries of the world. That is indeed an enviable record that the others aspire to. In general government current receipts as a share of GDP—or, broadly put, the level of income we gather mostly from taxation—Australia is the third lowest country in the OECD; that is, we are a low taxing country. In general government net debt interest on payments—that is, on government borrowings—what is our debt repayment? Of the 24 most developed countries in the world, Australia is equal fourth lowest—a sign of a very well managed public sector. These are fair comparisons between OECD figures. One ought to bear all of that performance in mind before conducting the economic sabotage that we have become used to from the opposition.

We have strong growth rates in Australia. In the last year we had 4.75 per cent which was strong and sustainable and in the year in view we will have 3.75 per cent. Tomorrow I am sure we will get a report from the Statistician in the national accounts which will show 16 consecutive quarters of sustained economic growth, one of the longest sustained periods of economic growth we have had since the Statistician kept these figures. We will be looking at a period of several years of continuing high levels of growth. We will be doing it against a low inflation background.

One of the great achievements of this government is to break the inflation stick. We are now going through, historically, one of the lowest periods of inflation that Australia has enjoyed. Importantly, we are enjoying low inflation against a background of high growth. The normal situation is that inflation rises, but we have kept it down. We will keep the underlying rate of inflation over the period between our target set by the Reserve Bank, supported by the Accord, committed to by the trade unions of Australia and aimed at by this government, between two and three per cent. The opposition never achieved that. In all its period of government in the most recent period it showed that it cannot do that. We have done that, and that is one of the great strengths of this economy.

Importantly, in jobs growth in the last year 380,000 jobs or more than 1,000 jobs a day were created by this government, delivering on its commitment of more than half a million jobs. We exceeded that. We created 618,000 jobs, and unemployment is now down to 8.1 per cent. Through the Accord, working with the major forces in our community, we have in view an ability to create 600,000 new jobs in the upcoming period. Business investment is 15 per cent, which is a very high level for Australia. I was at the Australia-Japan ministerial council meeting talking to the Australian and Japanese ministers on Friday. The new Prime Minister of Japan was there. The Japanese commended Australia on its ability to generate this high level of business investment.

Exports are running at very high levels. Elaborately transformed manufactures are at 13 per cent, and the level of taxation is among the lowest in the OECD. Against this background, one ought to come to the issue of the current account deficit because it has taken some attention here. The major reason why we are confident, why the business community is confident, why the economic commentators are confident and why most Australians should be confident that the current account deficit will fall as we have forecast in this coming budget by half a per cent of GDP is that our budget this year is in surplus. Our budget in the outgoing years is in surplus less asset sales and will grow in greater surplus. So we will be accumulating public savings.

As well as that, we have a superannuation scheme which will give Australians dignity in retirement—something that the opposition has withheld from them and withheld it on a fair, equitable basis. We will provide that but we will do so out of a pool of national savings generated by superannuation. In our period of office, living standards have risen 40 per cent on a household disposable income per capita basis—40 per cent in real living standards. What is the opposition's position with regard to all of this? While presenting the credentials of the government, one ought to contrast it with the lack of credentials of the opposition.

The last indication we have had of what might be something that passes for an economic policy from the opposition was the so-called second headland speech. What did it propose to do as a major vision in this country for the economy? It proposed three bodies of government economic advice and the amalgamation of them into one called the productivity council, and that would solve the problem. What a joke! There is no economist out there who believes that is any sort of solution. The opposition also said that it was going to cut government outlays. In the last session of parliament when we were getting the budget through, the opposition wanted to cut government outlays and voted in this chamber to do so. But the opposition now says to the public that it wants to increase outlays.

You voted to increase expenditure in the last session of parliament, and you have promised every interest group through each of your shadow ministers new expenditure which totals $9 billion on top of what is in the budget now. You say that you will cut expenditure. Where will you cut it? Of course you will cut it in health. You will demolish the health system of this country. Of course you will cut it in education. You will decrease the education funding, put Australians who are now in education out of education and lower the levels of education in this country. You will cut welfare payments, where Australians in a position unable to defend themselves will be denied the necessary support and the public compassion that a responsible government should demonstrate for those who are in an unfortunate situation in life. That is where you will cut it. There is no escaping that as a fundamental thrust of your policy. Those are indeed the implications of Mr Howard's speech.

Then you talk about micro-economic reform. As everyone in each state of Australia where there is a Liberal government knows, that is code for putting people in public employment on the scrap heap and out of work with no future, without improving the micro-efficiency of the economy at all. That is what you have done in Western Australia. That is what you are doing in South Australia. That is what you have done in Victoria. That is what you did in New South Wales under a Liberal government, and that is what you would do federally if you were in power.

The final thing is your industrial relations policy. You believe that your industrial relations policy will improve things. But no-one else believes that. The Confederation of WA Industry—a very conservative body—does not believe that. The mining companies of Western Australia do not believe that; the independent commentators in the West Australian, a conservative paper, do not believe that. All have said so; all have said that your industrial relations policies are a disaster and would exacerbate the current account because we would have a lack of confidence in this country by our international trading partners. They would think of us as an unreliable supplier and that would be a direct consequence of your industrial relations policies.(Time expired)
