TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are being told that Australians do not have confidence in our future. We are asking why. The government says we have never had it better; we are moving into the economic nirvana of a low inflation recovery. Senator Cook has told us that 618,000 new jobs have been created since 1993, but he did not tell us that over half of them were part-time jobs. There were record exports in July and there have been 16 quarters of positive economic growth. You cannot say that these are not achievements, because they are achievements and they should not be dismissed.

PARA.TAB: Underpinning those achievements is the government's Achilles heel; that is, the highest current account deficit in the OECD. We as a nation are spending $106 for every $100 we earn. Really, 12 years of Mr Keating—whether as Treasurer or Prime Minister—have failed to fix this chronic problem. We have heard the government crying—perhaps with a bit of relief, I suspect—about today's current account deficit. After the $3 billion peak in May, we are now down to $2.1 billion. We are heading in the right direction, thank goodness; but we still have the eighth highest monthly deficit on record.

SPEECH.PARA: Within the current account there are two clear problems. While exports are rising so are imports, especially—as others have said today—consumption goods imports. In July, consumption goods jumped nine per cent while capital goods fell nine per cent. That means that fewer of our imports are for business investment and many more are for household consumption. Increasingly, if you look at the evidence, Australians are using borrowings to fund those imports. In the last three years household borrowing has exploded. Housing finance is up by 70 per cent and personal finance is up by 13 per cent, while lending to business has remained static.

PARA.TAB: In a previous debate in this place I recall the government telling us that we should not worry because this is all self-managing. But our household savings ratio has fallen. It is a third of the level it was a decade ago. That is despite the superannuation guarantee charge system's introduction. Government spending has also increased, as this government has failed to meet its spending commitments with fully funded revenue and expenditure measures. So with this debt explosion feeding into the current account, our interest rates have been pushed up. They are at the highest level in the Western world.

We are asking the question: are Australians confident about their economic future? At one level, the growing levels of household debt suggest people are very confident—too confident perhaps—about their economic future. Either that or they still very strongly believe that `she'll be right'. I think this is something that is quite prevalent in government policy circles as well as in the Australian psyche.

It is hard to say, though, in terms of this matter of public importance, that it is all the government's fault; that it can all be laid at the feet of Paul Keating. Because when you look at the big policy decisions of the last 12 years, what do you see? Financial deregulation—the opposition supported it with bells on. Ludicrous unilateral tariff reduction—the opposition supported it. There have been second thoughts, though, from both since then. Competition policy, as yet an untried and unproven wind-back of government—the opposition voted for it. Enterprise bargaining—the opposition suggested it. Asset sales, tighter monetary policy—the opposition voted and called for it. The point I would make is that, so far, there has not been a definitive policy difference except for the GST, which is now buried, we are told.

The pollsters tell us that Australians despair of our political system. They despair of our behaviour this week, in particular, but they also feel that issues are so complex and the options provided by the government and opposition are so similar that they feel a little powerless. In response, across the country, voters are lashing out at whoever is in power—Labor or Liberal. What Australians want to hear is not more oversell and hyperbole from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about how good it is and how we have never had it better. They also do not want to hear a constant whingeing recitation from Mr Costello about how bad it is, promising that micro-economic reform will solve everything.

What Australians want to know, I think, from both government and opposition, what they want to feel confidence in, is that there is a clear plan in place to attack our chronic current account problem. They want to have confidence that Australia's economic future will be decided here in Australia and not in the boardrooms of the foreign bankers and investors who own or control an increasing share of our country and economy. Until the opposition tells us their master plan to deal with this and while we can certainly say Mr Keating's government has failed, we cannot yet say that the opposition should not share some of the blame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is about the failure of the government's economic policy. That failure is dramatically illustrated today by the release of yet another disastrous current account deficit monthly figure, yet another figure over $2,000 million. This is the ninth month in a row where we have had a deficit on the current account of over $2 billion. We have had a deficit of over $2 billion in all but one of the last 13 months. We now have a total net foreign debt, as at March this year, of $167 billion, a figure that is just mind-boggling and beyond the comprehension, probably, of most Australians.

PARA.TAB: The debt build-up under Labor has been absolutely massive. We have had a current account deficit in every year of Labor's reign. We now have a foreign debt which is being added to by more than the debt was when Labor came to office. When they came to office the debt was $23 billion. After 195 years we had built up a debt of $23 billion. We are now adding to the foreign debt a figure each year that exceeds that amount.

In 1994-95 the foreign deficit was $27 billion; and it is going to be another $27 billion this year. That is more than the total debt was after 195 years when this government came to office. It is a disastrous record of which this government should be utterly ashamed. The current account deficit problem is the best indicator of how hopeless this government's economic management is. To the great chagrin of Labor members, voters do understand this problem. I think the Labor Party is operating on the presumption that voters do not really understand anything about the current account.

There was a very interesting poll in the 1 August Bulletin. It published some results of questions voters were asked about the current account. It showed that voters rate the size of the current account deficit as the fourth most important problem facing voters as they go to vote. As an issue it is beaten only by health, education and unemployment which, of course, are also very significant problems facing this country.

Voters were asked how aware they are of the size of the current account deficit. Some 65 per cent said they are well aware of it. Then they were asked how well they understand the term `current account deficit' and 62 per cent said they understand it very well. As the Bulletin said:

SPEECH.PARA: The poll reveals that voter concern about Australia's record current account deficit is very high . . . respondents rate it higher than interest rates as an issue of great importance.
The problem for Labor backbenchers is shown by the reporter saying:
Privately, backbenchers say they have been banking on voter ignorance about the current account . . .

This poll gives the lie to that idea and should send a chill through every Labor backbencher when voters go to the polls, because voters clearly understand the problem. The government well understands the problem of the current account and that is why Keating made his infamous banana republic speech in 1986. He understands the problem but, nine years later, it is even worse than it was when he said we were going down the path of becoming a banana republic.

PARA.TAB: The tragedy is that in 1990 Mr Keating himself deliberately engineered the worst recession we have had in 60 years in order to deal with the current account problem. That is apparently why we had to have the recession—to deal with the current account problem. We have had the recession. The recession laid waste to the Australian economy and to the lives of ordinary Australians, it ruined thousands upon thousands of small businesses, drove thousands of Australians out of their homes and wrecked the lives of a lot of Australians. For what? Why did we have this recession? What have we achieved as a result of having the recession which Mr Keating said we had to have? We have gained absolutely nothing from that recession. All we have done is lose—lose the lives and businesses of thousands of Australians.

The debt problem is now worse than before. It is worse than when the recession came into effect. The legacy of all this is that we have, as Senator Hill pointed out, the highest nominal interest rates in the world—and probably the highest real interest rates. Many of us read the Economist. The latest Economist has a chart on interest rates. As Senator Hill pointed out, the prime bank rate for Australia is 11 1/2 per cent. The only other country with an interest rate anything like that is Italy, which also has a rate of 11 1/2 per cent. All of the other countries are much lower. The economy of Britain has a level of only 7 3/4 per cent and Japan only two per cent.

We really have horrendously high interest rates and they are a direct result of this government's economic mismanagement and of the problem of the current account debt. Ross Gittins made this point recently in the Sydney Morning Herald. Most voters do understand the current account deficit, but they also understand the consequences. Ross Gittins said:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in fact, is the main way that the current account deficit and high foreign debt affect our daily lives: they cause the interest rates we pay on home loans and everything else to be higher than they'd otherwise be.
That is the legacy for Labor. That is the problem for ordinary Australian voters caused by the debt which has been built up by this government and by its inadequate response to the problem.

PARA.TAB: That is our real message to the government. The government have failed to come to grips with the size of this problem. They tried killing it with a recession—it did not work. They have failed to come up with the policy response to deal with this problem, which is underpinning our high interest rates. There really is a universal view among economists about what has to be done and about the failure of this government to take the course which must be followed.

Fixing this current account deficit problem does require a range of measures. It primarily requires labour market reform. As I say, there is universal agreement through the corporate community, the finance community and market economists that the fact that this government is in hock to the trade union movement and will not deal with this issue of labour market reform is preventing Australia dealing with the current account problem.

There is no attempt to reform the tax system. The tax system is worse, more complicated, more difficult and more inhibiting of investment and business activity than it was when Labor came to power. They refuse to deal with tax reform. Reform of federal-state financial relations has hit a wall. Nothing is happening on that front. Those are the three principal areas where action must be taken if we are to deal with the current account problem.

The government announced that the superannuation policy is going to fix everything. If we let the government get carried away with its hyperbole on superannuation policy, it would probably say that the policy would fix the drought. The problem with the government's rhetoric on this is that it seems to me the government is ignoring all the other policy areas where it should be acting because it is putting all its eggs in the basket of superannuation policy. It is not clear that superannuation policy will add significantly to savings. It is blinding the government to the need for reform in all the other areas.

The government's record on economic management is one of boom-bust. We go from boom to bust, and it looks like we are heading for another bust. Interest rates and inflation are heading up—the former Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank recently warned about inflation and the problems of high interest rates. But there was never more true a statement than John Howard's statement that, under this government, after the recession we have had five minutes of economic sunshine and now it is back down to the bust.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will be interesting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wheelwright Sen T.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly will, Senator. I am glad you are listening so carefully. By any measure, I think it has to be said, the Australian economy now is in far superior health than it was at the beginning of 1983. Let me take you back to the circumstances that this government inherited. We inherited a state of stagflation. That is not a word that has been heard in this chamber very often in recent times because it simply does not apply to this government. Stagflation is low growth, high inflation and high unemployment.

PARA.TAB: That is exactly what this government inherited from the Howard coalition. Any sort of comparison will demonstrate that. Inflation was running at 11.5 per cent when John Howard handed over the economy. It is currently running at 4.5 per cent and in an underlying rate it has been running at 2.5 per cent for the last three years. That is the state of inflation.

Let us nail the lie now about this so-called five minutes of economic sunshine. Exactly what is this five minutes of economic sunshine? I will tell you what it is. In the September quarter of 1994, the economy grew at an annual rate of 6.1 per cent. Anybody who believes that that is economic sunshine is an economic madman. That is exactly what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was referring to when he said `economic sunshine'.

If anybody believes that is economic sunshine, they are willing to ignore all of the bottlenecks that that creates in the economy; they are willing to ignore the scramble for labour at any price; they are prepared to ignore asset price inflation, which is an inevitable conclusion; and they are prepared to ignore the diversion of goods from export markets to the domestic markets, which always happens when you run the economy at an unsustainable rate of growth. That is exactly what we had during that period. Anybody who believes that that is economic sunshine is simply an economic speed junkie. You would have to run the economy on amyl nitrite full time to get that sort of growth. The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) has already given a clear indication of this government's strength in its enormous creation of jobs—618,000 jobs have been created in its term. What did senators opposite manage to produce? In their whole term of government they produced 400,000 jobs. The creation of jobs was a central promise of this government at the time of the last election and it has been absolutely delivered.

In terms of the balance of payments, which senators opposite seek to make so much about, I refer them to a recent article I put in the Telegraph Mirror on 31 June 1995 in which I identify the four great lies that members opposite are keen to tell. You might even remember this, Senator. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is undeniable that Australia has become dependent to some considerable degree on overseas investment to make good deficits on the current balance of payments and we can see little prospect that this will be changed.

PARA.TAB: Lie No. 2, which you are so often keen to trot out, is that our balance of payments is worse than it has ever been. I think Senator Cook showed quite clearly that, by any reasonable measure, the external account is improving under this government. In other words, our export performance is outstripping our import performance by any reasonable sort of measure.

Lie No. 3 about the balance of payments is that we cannot compete. Ten years ago Australia imported five times more manufactured goods than we exported. In just 10 years we have halved that because our exports have outstripped our imports.

SPEECH.PARA: CRIMES AMENDMENT (CONTROLLED OPERATIONS) BILL 1995

On 19 April 1995 the High Court handed down its decision in the matter of Ridgeway v The Queen. By a majority of 6-1 the court decided that where law enforcement officials use a controlled operation during an investigation into narcotics trafficking and, as a result, commit an element of an offence with which a defendant is charged, a court should normally refuse to admit the evidence of that element against the defendant. Some members of the court indicated that if law enforcement officers are to engage in unlawful conduct in the course of investigations, a legislative scheme authorising this conduct would need be established.

PARA.TAB: The bill that is now before the Senate responds to that judgment. The bill will ensure that there is a legislative base for controlled operations by law enforcement agencies and that the officers participating in such operations are protected from criminal responsibility for conduct undertaken in the course of their duty. The bill will also provide an avenue for the admission of evidence obtained from controlled operations prior to its commencement, provided the operation was conducted in conformity with established procedures.

Many people, both in the chamber and in the community, might ask: why should we sanction the police participating in criminal activity? Won't this activity lead to the entrapment of people? Won't it be an inducement for the committing of crimes that would otherwise not occur? They might say that there are many dangers in sanctioning these covert operations. I will respond to each of these questions.

Drug crime is peculiarly difficult to combat. Rarely are there complainants about this conduct. The importation of large quantities of drugs is a clandestine criminal activity involving complicity, or participants who will remain silent for fear of retribution. Organised crime does not tolerate complaint.

As a result, the struggle against this trade involves very difficult choices for us as legislators and for the community. We are all committed to the preservation of fundamental values such as equality, privacy, freedom of expression, the right to a fair trial and so on. Equally however there is the right of the individual to protection by the state. There is a powerful public interest in opposing the spread of illegal drug trafficking, and the official corruption that it can spawn.

Good law enforcement is a citizen's entitlement. It must be borne in mind that loss of confidence in law enforcement will lead governments to measures destructive of civil liberties. This is not such a bill. The choice before us is between a society prepared to accept balanced legislation to counter criminals, and a society poisoned by the conditions created by those criminals and their activities.

The bill lays down a full and open system of accountability. The bill requires that the responsible Minister, at present myself, is kept informed of all applications for the authority to conduct a controlled operation. In turn, the responsible Minister is required to table a report in Parliament providing details of the applications made under the provisions of the bill.

The procedure will not lead to `entrapment' of people. A controlled operation may be conducted only in circumstances where the targets of the operation are likely to import (or export) narcotics whether or not the operation takes place. The bill will ensure that it will not be permissible for officers to procure the commission of offences which otherwise would not have taken place.

The law as regards accepting or rejecting evidence obtained by improper methods will be maintained. However controlled operations may lead to the detection of principals whose activities might otherwise never be discovered, let alone prosecuted.
I should emphasise that controlled operations are an internationally accepted investigatory technique.

On 14 February 1993 the Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances came into force in Australia. That Convention was implemented by legislation that commenced operation that same day. Article 11(1) of the Convention provides as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Article 11—Controlled delivery

PARA.TAB: 1. If permitted by the basic principles of their respective domestic legal systems, the parties shall take the necessary measures, within their possibilities, to allow for the appropriate use of controlled delivery at the international level, on the basis of agreements or arrangements mutually consented to, with a view to identifying persons involved in offences established in accordance with article 3, paragraph 1, and to taking legal action against them.

This article indicates the recognition by the international community of the need to employ specialised investigative techniques, like the controlled operation, to deal with organised and sophisticated traffickers.

In Australia the report of the Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct (commonly known as the Fitzgerald report) also discussed the use of new techniques in combating organised crime. Commissioner Fitzgerald concluded that an effective response to organised crime is dependent upon recognition of four factors:

SPEECH.PARA: the social changes which crime causes and the fact that it diminishes the quality of life;
the fact that crime escalates if it is not controlled;
recognition that there are vulnerabilities in the social order which expose it to exploitation; and
the steps that are needed to control crime.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the latter point (the steps that are needed to control crime) Commissioner Fitzgerald stated that consideration should be given to a wide range of measures which would equip law enforcement agencies with new powers including permitting `the infiltration of criminal groups'. Commissioner Fitzgerald concluded that orthodox policing is quite unable to enforce the law.
This bill will ensure that Commonwealth law enforcement agencies have available to them the controlled operation as a tool in the investigation of the trade in narcotics.

I turn now to discuss briefly the key features of the bill. The central issue in the Ridgeway decision was the admissibility of evidence. The High Court held that because of the involvement of law enforcement agents in the importation of heroin, the evidence obtained thereby was fatally tainted and should be excluded from the trial of the principal conspirator. Honourable Senators may notice that the bill before them says nothing about the admissibility of evidence. How then, it might be asked, does the bill respond to the decision of the High Court?

The basis for the decision by the majority of the High Court was that a trial judge has a discretion to exclude evidence on certain public policy grounds. The public policy ground in question, which then triggers the discretion to exclude evidence, arises where illegal police conduct is an essential ingredient of the charged offence. In such a case there will be `an extremely formidable case for exclusion' of the evidence by the trial judge.

The High Court accepted that the legislature could sanction the use of controlled operations and that such a legislative regime could exempt the officers from the requirements of the criminal law. The court went on to say that `in the absence of such a legislative regime, the courts have no choice but to set their face firmly against grave criminality on the part of anyone, regardless of whether he or she be government officer or ordinary citizen.' The enactment of the bill now before the Senate will ensure that the actions of law enforcement officials engaged in a controlled operation will not incur criminal responsibility and, as a result, the trigger for the exclusion of evidence will not arise.

It should be noted that the bill, whilst protecting the law enforcement officers from criminal responsibility, will still preserve the essential criminality or unlawfulness of the importation (or exportation) of the prohibited narcotics. This will ensure that the importation or exportation itself is not made lawful, thereby exonerating the targets of the operation who planned the conspiracy.

It is important to describe the effect of the bill upon prosecutions that are current at the time the bill commences operation. There are a number of investigations that are affected by the decision in Ridgeway. They all involve very significant participation in trafficking in narcotics, for example:

SPEECH.PARA: Conspiracy to import 7 kg of cocaine (one individual);
Being knowingly concerned in the importation of 3.8 kg of cocaine (two individuals);
Conspiracy to import 7 kg of cocaine (one individual); and
Being knowingly concerned in the importation of, and possession of, 2 kg of heroin (two individuals).

PARA.TAB: Controlled operations were employed in each of these matters. These operations were strictly regulated and rigorously controlled covert operations. They were not operations involving out of control cowboys riding roughshod over our laws. In each case they were conducted in purported accordance with the terms of a Ministerial agreement relating to such operations and the detailed requirements of Australian Federal Police guidelines on the conduct of controlled operations.

The Ministerial agreement was entered into on 3 June 1987 between the then Special Minister of State (having responsibility for the Australian Federal Police) Senator the Honourable Michael Tate, and the then Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (having responsibility for the Australian Customs Service) Senator the Honourable John Button. The agreement provided that a written request was to be made to the Australian Customs Service:

`where certain persons, goods, ships or aircraft, suspected or known to be carrying or having an involvement in drugs, are required by the Australian Federal Police or the National Crime Authority to be exempted from detailed customs scrutiny and control and in cases where there is to be substitution of imported goods'.

Once that agreement was obtained the operation was conducted in accordance with detailed requirements of Australian Federal Police guidelines. These guidelines run to fifty paragraphs and closely regulate the considerations that should be adverted to when deciding whether a controlled operation should be conducted; the level at which operations must be approved; the procedures for a controlled delivery involving the substitution of the narcotic substance; further procedures for those operations where substitution is not feasible or possible; the requirements for analysis of the narcotic substance; and the making of payments to couriers and informants.

These operations were conducted pursuant to these guidelines. The operations were closely monitored. Each of the accused alleged to have been detected as a result of these controlled operations are entitled to a fair trial and the presumption of innocence. But without the passage of this legislation those trials will have to be abandoned. I believe the community would not see that to be a just outcome.

In conclusion I believe that the community expects that law enforcement agencies will make every effort to catch the Mr Bigs, not just apprehend couriers and the dealers on our street corners. Indeed the community has a right to expect, to demand, that law enforcement agencies will act to protect them, and their children who are particularly vulnerable. This bill will satisfy that demand by providing a firm legislative basis for the use of controlled operations as a device in combating drug trafficking.
Other aspects of the bill are described in the Explanatory Memorandum which I now present.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: PUBLIC ORDER (PROTECTION OF PERSONS AND PROPERTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

It has become apparent that existing Commonwealth law does not adequately protect persons attending Federal Courts and tribunals. Currently police and other officers responsible for the safety of such persons do not have adequate protective powers to ensure a secure environment, particularly in circumstances where weapons and even explosive devices may be simply concealed in the clothing of a person, or in personal effects such as brief cases.

PARA.TAB: The Government considers that it would be proper to provide legislative powers to assist Commonwealth courts to maintain security and protect the safety of both court staff and persons attending proceedings. Comparable legislation was enacted in Victoria in 1980 and Queensland in 1983.

While Commonwealth courts have an inherent jurisdiction to control and protect persons in relation to proceedings, the scope is uncertain. Police have, for example, been unclear about their powers to assist in the removal of persons from Family Court premises. What powers are available to search persons entering a court for weapons? The Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act 1971 currently includes a statutory offence of refusing to leave Commonwealth premises without reasonable excuse when directed by a person with power to give such directions. This offence has limited application with respect to persons who are parties to court or tribunal proceedings (and who may have a `reasonable excuse' to disregard such an order), and it does not provide for associated security powers, such as searching for, and the detention of, firearms, explosive devices, and offensive weapons.

Legislative provisions are required to empower police and other authorised officials to take action in situations which raise a threat to the security of Federal courts and tribunals. The amendments to the Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act 1971 propose a scheme of protective security, consistent with the electronic screening undertaken at the entrance to Parliament House and at airports but also allowing for `frisk' searches (in the nature of `pat down' search). Such screening is designed to identify security risks, while associated powers allow authorised officers to direct persons to leave the premises.

The possession of weapons in the court environment constitutes a serious threat to the ability of courts to function as a public forum. This is most apparent with respect to the Family Court. The sad history of violence directed at Family Court judges and those involved in such proceedings is a constant reminder that security is an issue that should be taken seriously.

Although the legislation is the result of concerns emanating from events in the Family Court, the amendments can be applied to all Federal courts or tribunals by regulation. The powers provided in the Act will not be available to all Federal courts and tribunals as a matter of course. Only such powers as are considered necessary by responsible officials having regard to the circumstances faced by a Federal court or tribunal in a particular location will be available. This means that the identification and management of security requirements will be initiated by the court or tribunal itself. Regulations will be made only at the request of the court or tribunal.

The security powers provided in the legislation will be exercised by authorised officers. This term is defined to include police officers as well as persons who are authorised by the Attorney-General, or by courts empowered to administer their own affairs. This provision addresses the concern that police will have to be solely responsible for the implementation of various separate security regimes at diverse premises. By providing for the authorisation of court or security officers, responsible specifically for the security of particular sites, the police can be utilised more flexibly to deal only with serious breaches of security.

Powers held by police and authorised officers may include requiring a person attending prescribed premises to provide his or her name, address, evidence of identity, and a reason for being on the premises. The legislation makes it clear that a wish to attend the proceedings of the court is an acceptable reason, and access will be available unless the person has not complied with the security arrangements in place at that court or tribunal.

The Government is sensitive to the criticism that exercise of the powers will discourage members of the public from attending court cases and thus undermine the principle that justice should be dispensed in public. I reiterate that the Government is concerned to preserve the open and public administration of justice, whilst at the same time providing adequate protection to those participating in that administration.

Australia has been fortunate that violent attacks upon our judicial system have been few and far between. Unfortunately, apart from the well known incidence involving the Family Court, there have been occasions at the State and Territory level where people have been injured or killed in court buildings. Furthermore, recent tragic events in Oklahoma City remind us of the fragility and vulnerability of our open society. Governments have a responsibility to take all reasonable steps to ensure the safety and security of those involved in our judicial system.

Regulations will be made to govern the management of information gathered about persons attending court in accordance with the Privacy Act 1988. The Government is aware that persons attending courts will be concerned about the possible uses of information so gathered, and the regulations will address these concerns.

Authorised officers are empowered to search persons using screening devices—for example, devices similar to those which are commonly used at airports—and/or by a `frisk' search, conducted by quickly running hands over the outer clothing. It is envisaged that the use of screening equipment will be employed in most cases. Frisk searches will only be undertaken by persons of the same sex. Persons may also be required to deposit personal effects reasonably capable of concealing a firearm, explosive substance or offensive weapon. This power may be utilised, for example, where the goods in question cannot be adequately searched, or where the security requirements of a particular court or tribunal do not warrant the installation of electronic screening mechanisms.

Although authorised officers are empowered to direct persons in breach of any requirement to leave the premises, enforcement of these requests can be made only by the police, in accordance with conditions set out in section 22 of the Act.

This promotes flexibility in the enforcement of the security regulations at a basic level, by allowing courts themselves to determine appropriate security responses. It also ensures the involvement of the police in any potentially serious situation, where the person concerned refuses a lawful direction not to enter, or to leave, the premises.

Four new offences have been created to assist with the enforcement of the provisions. It will be an offence to refuse or fail to give information, or to give false information, in response to a lawful request; to refuse or fail, without reasonable excuse, to submit to a required search or to deposit certain personal effects with an authorised officer; to refuse or fail to comply with a direction to leave court premises; or to bring any firearm, explosive substance or offensive weapon onto prescribed premises without lawful excuse.

The opportunity has also been taken to make a number of minor amendments, including updating the penalty provisions of the Act. The removal of gender specific language, and the updating of property valuations throughout the Act has also been completed.

It is hoped that the amendments will bring about a significant improvement in the provision of security services to Commonwealth courts and tribunals. With such measures in place both staff and persons attending prescribed premises will be more confident of their safety.
The amendments will have no significant financial impact.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, the Government has developed a bold plan to provide Australians with higher retirement incomes and to boost national saving and investment.

PARA.TAB: Compulsory superannuation is the cornerstone of the Government's strategy. Since the late 1980's, employers have contributed for their employees under awards and the Superannuation Guarantee. As a result, over 90 per cent of Australian employees now have superannuation, up from less than 40 per cent a decade ago.
The Treasurer announced a further boost to superannuation in the last Budget.

From 1997, many employees will begin making their own superannuation contributions paid from award wage rises. In addition, most workers making superannuation contributions will be able to claim a matching Government payment in their tax returns.
The result is that most workers will have the equivalent of 15 per cent of salary paid into superannuation by the year 2003.

The Government remains firmly committed to maintaining the pension for those who need it. Our policies mean Australians will have more income in retirement through a combination of superannuation and part pension.
Superannuation assets are expected to increase tenfold in the next 25 years. This brings important responsibilities for both the Government and the private sector.

establishing the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal to provide redress to people in dispute with their fund;
taking steps to protect small superannuation balances being eroded by fees and charges;

DEBATE.TITLE: AIRCRAFT NOISE LEVY BILL 1995AIRCRAFT NOISE LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 August, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these bills be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Senator Parer had moved by way of amendment:
At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate condemns the Government for its callous and incompetent policy on Sydney Airport, and condemns it in particular:

PARA.TAB: (a)for misleading the people of Sydney about the noise that would be associated with the opening of the parallel runway and the closure of the east west runway; and

(b)for its failure to develop adequate noise management measures prior to the opening of the parallel runway and the closure of the east west runway, rather than after it had opened in a belated response to community pressure".

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the Airport Noise Levy Bill 1995 and the Airport Noise Levy Collection Bill 1995. I see that the government has adopted another so-called `green tax'. This bill is designed to tax noise pollution at the Sydney airport. As in many cases, this tax is not designed to stop noise pollution. It will just make some money for the federal government.

PARA.TAB: The bill demonstrates just how cynical this government's so-called green taxes can actually be. It will add $32 million dollars to government coffers, and it will cost each passenger an extra $3.40 per trip. But the passengers will have little idea of the addition since, when they ask the cost of a ticket, this will presumably just be included on the ticket. In any case, a passenger to Sydney has no options. He or she is not going to go to Melbourne, either as good citizens trying to avoid having negative impacts on others—although they might in some cases choose not to go through Sydney as a connection—or in order to try to avoid paying the cost of a sandwich in an airport lounge. She or he has no control over what airports are available, at what airports the planes land, where the airports are, what level of housing exists or is planned around the airport, or which flight paths are dictated. None of these things are in the control of the passengers who will have to pay for any bad judgments.

People who do make the decisions—the Civil Aviation Authority, the state government and the Federal Department of Transport—are not going to have to pay. There will be no incentive, aside from popular political pressure, to change the decisions they have made or to provide better alternatives. A more effective method of fundraising might be to demand that the cost of amelioration of the problems is taken out of the budgets of the organisations who help create them. I will bet we would see stronger and more effective action a lot more quickly that way.

Of course, the other people who pay in the most direct way possible are the residents who have to put up with the noise. I note that there is nothing here that indicates any guarantee or level of funding to address the problem. Nor is there any mention of what should be done about it. One thing the exmo for this bill did say is that, while the description of applicable airport only fits the Kingsford Smith airport in Sydney, it could be expanded. I wonder whether this is an indication that the government wants to raise more revenue and thinks this is a good way to do so, or whether this means that it foresees similar problems with other airports and in other cities.

Certainly, those on the Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney have indicated that there are similar problems in other cities—Adelaide, Melbourne and Perth—where there are possible other runways planned. I notice that rather than address the real problem—that is, perhaps primarily the level of air transport used as opposed to other attractive forms of transport, to the extent perhaps of unnecessary air travel in Australia—we could, even in this parliament, make greater use of electronic transport. Rather than transporting people right across the country several times, perhaps in non-sitting periods, to appear before a committee, they could attend by way of televideo conferencing.

The other major issue is that flight paths have a huge impact and housing should not be planned under major flight paths. There should not be major flight paths over major areas of population. If you do have those things, you have got to be aware of the fact that that is part of the real cost of air travel and that cost should be built in. If it is not built in, then we have no means of ameliorating it. We have to realise that there is a cost associated with it and plan it in, instead of pretending it does not exist.

The problems themselves are horrific. We are talking about having to live in situations where frequent, intermittent noise of 80 to 90 decibels or higher becomes a fact of life. This level of noise shakes buildings and completely destroys amenity for the residents. It is awful enough on a visit—and I have been there—but imagine having to live on a continual basis with such noise. Let us look at what government seems willing to do about this.

The noise amelioration programs that this tax is supposed to pay for consist of putting noise insulation into houses of residents. Residents complain that the level of insulation originally promised has steadily declined. Not only is a lower standard to be installed, but the insulation does not cover key areas of sound entry. More importantly, apparently the insulation program does not cover the entire house. It only covers sleeping and relaxing rooms. There is apparently no intention of insulating rooms such as the kitchen and dining room. This could be equivalent to a whole area of Sydney being under permanent house arrest.

Most people will know that in a normal house, the kitchen is one of the most heavily used rooms, especially where there is a big kitchen built to accommodate a kitchen table. The kitchen is the room where you have breakfast in the morning, where the kids come in after school, where homework is done, and often where dinner is eaten. It is also a room used far more by women and children, so there are gender issues. Why is it considered a room where people have to put up with the noise of living under a runway?

The whole insulation plan is questionable. Evidence given to the committee is that the insulation plan is entirely uncoordinated. It seems to involve illegal installations and it is far more expensive than the government is willing to admit to, as well as being inadequate to ameliorate the noise. There are also problems of who does and who does not get insulation and who does and who does not get compensation. It seems that these kinds of decisions have been entirely arbitrary, based on straight lines, where you can get a person straight under the flight path getting insulation expenditure paid and the person next door not getting it. It is not that the person next door gets zero aircraft noise and the person who gets insulation gets 80 or 90 per cent of aircraft noise; or perhaps the person whose house gets bought out from under them gets compensation. It is not worked on a percentage basis. It is worked on an arbitrary, you get it or you don't basis, and there is a line drawn down the street.

Evidence presented to the select committee on aircraft noise—I note especially the evidence at the end of the first of this month—is that the means of measuring aircraft sound appears to be averaged to guarantee that the figure is as much as 10 decibels lower than the actual noise for some of the aircraft, 10 decibels lower than the levels that people actually have to put up with. For those who are not familiar with decibels, they are measured on a logarithmic scale. As a result, the increase in sound of 10 decibels means the sound is 10 times higher. So an increase of 20 decibels means that it is 100 times higher. So the difference between the actual sound and the average amount used by the government is about 10 times louder in order of magnitude.

As a result, the level of insulation is not going to be calculated to ameliorate the actual noise. The actual noise will be 10 times louder than the noise the insulation was designed to ameliorate. As to the insulation strategy itself, we have already noted that commonly used and commonly lived in parts of the house, like the kitchen-dining room or the bathroom, will not be insulated. Those parts will get the full blast of sound. There will be no pleasant baths and making dinner will become a hellish torment. People will eat in their lounge rooms rather than put up with the noise—and even there they will hear the planes because the insulation is not adequate.

The essence of the insulation program is to fill the roof with insulation, fill the walls, double seal the windows and make them unable to be opened, rip out any glass, any leadlighting, put in solid doors, seal them and seal all the edges. Basically, the plan is to create a hermetically sealed and insulated cocoon. How do people breathe?

The government plans to put in forced draft ventilation. Unfortunately, this ventilation does not have the ability to heat and cool. Every 30 minutes or so it will replace the air in the house so that people do not suffocate. In winter, this means that all the warm air will be sucked out and replaced with fresh cold air. In summer, this means all the cooler air inside is periodically sucked out and replaced with the hot air from outside. From an energy efficiency standpoint, and from a comfort standpoint, any possible benefit from insulating the house will be completely cancelled by the ventilation system. It will be even worse in terms of heating and cooling than a uninsulated house in a normal suburb.

The ventilators require energy and cost money to run. Estimates run at between $1,000 and $2,000 per year. Think of the extra money that then has to be put in to a maintain a house at a decent temperature. Here is the killer: part of the insulation program consists of blocking any chimney or flues by filling them with insulation. If you have a fireplace or slow combustion heater you will have to find some other way to heat your house and you will have to use that device often because any air you heat will be cycled out of the vent every 30 minutes or so.

As well as that, the ventilators are noisy. The ventilators often have no star ratings and seem to be of low quality, if those people who have made submissions are to be believed. One submission stated that schools got even lower quality ventilation to save money. It was also pointed out that the ventilators were so noisy that students could not study. The ventilators that let you breathe in these hermetically sealed rooms designed to reduce aircraft noise are so noisy that they have to be insulated separately, according to the evidence of Mr Clinton on page 807 of the select committee Hansard.

Mr Clinton and others giving evidence during the hearings also noted that the insulation used gives off gases causing health problems. Some of it is flammable or potentially flammable and gives off high level toxic gases when burnt. In installations in the test areas, the electrical wiring was buried in a way that it could not be maintained. There was no upgrading of old electrical wiring to cope with the demand of the new ventilation and airconditioning systems and probably the increased use and application of power in heating and cooling the house. There is no plan for addressing the fact that some of the houses and buildings have asbestos roofs and other panels.

Mr Clinton also informed the committee that representatives of the fire brigade, Sydney Electricity in relation to the insulation and wiring, and CFMEU in relation to industrial safety, were all ignorant of the plans and had grave concerns about various aspects of the program and its implementation. We are talking about a major program. We are talking about some 4,200 houses, 72 schools, hospitals, churches and so on. This has not been given sufficient consideration. If we see the line the government takes as establishing a precedent, we are likely to see it repeated in other major cities developing similar problems.

It occurred to me when I was in Sydney that the major problem may not be the one that is immediately obvious. The problem may be that the land in those areas is becoming so unsaleable because of the implications of aircraft noise that some time in the future—considering the proposed sell-off of federal airports land—the land may well be very attractive. It seems to me that the people living in and around the areas that experience this aircraft noise may be pawns in a game that eventually may make the sale of Sydney airport more attractive.

You could perhaps operate a very attractive undercover commercial centre like those that have been suggested for some of the other airport sites around Australia. It would be interesting if in a few years from now that became part of the sale package. It would be very easy to get hold of the land from those people who have been treated so badly and have been forced to leave, have sold out, died or something as a result of the way this whole nasty business has been handled.

There have been big promises. Mr Brereton promised the world's best practice in noise amelioration. That has apparently been cut back to Australian standards and below. Corners have been cut wherever possible and the government now claims that it need not insulate parts of the houses that are basic to living. The costs imposed to maintain ventilation, heating and cooling are apparently massive. Estimates considered to be reasonably accurate show that the cost of the program is likely to be around $350 million, yet the solution appears to be really quite inadequate. It will make only part of people's houses uncomfortable but livable, while extensively increasing their power bills, making their houses possible fatal fire traps, exposing them to environmentally hazardous chemical emissions and rendering their electrical wiring effectively unserviceable.

This is not a solution. This is a very expensive bandaid applied to a major civic wound. What are people's options? They can sell up, leave their homes, leave their friends and leave their neighbourhoods which have often been chosen for convenience or other reasons. The government valuers are valuing people's properties at up to $100,000 less than those of independent valuers. Even when those valuers try to work out the difference in valuation, the government estimates are still up to $50,000 less than those of independent valuers.

It seems that anyone wishing to sell to the government would not get enough to buy a comparable house in the region. No private buyer would move into that area and pay anything like a price similar to what they pay for a similar house not under a flight path. Why would they when they cannot use the yard or the kitchen and possibly cannot use the bathroom without putting up with full aircraft noise?

This is not a solution. There is no good effective method of amelioration in a situation like this short of building a huge biosphere over the area. A solution would involve stopping the flights over people's houses or at least paying enough compensation to allow people to make a decent exit from the area without losing much of their investment.

This tax is liable to be less than will cover the cost of even a decent go at the amelioration promised and planned. The Greens will support the levy because it is more or less sure to go to the amelioration programs. We put the government on notice that in our opinion this level of amelioration is not a solution; it is an excuse to continue to do stupid things. The levy is almost certainly inadequate to cover costs and we think the whole thing is a botched job from beginning to end and satisfies no-one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking in this debate on this legislation for Senator Bourne, who is engaged elsewhere. I will pick up a couple of points which Senator Margetts has just made. What we are dealing with here is part of the costs of growth and part of the costs of the continual expansion of our economic system. We are wanting our population to grow and the number of tourists coming into this country to grow, but what we are seeing here is the downside of that pressure for growth. We are also seeing that the costs of that downside are unequally shared. Those in the more distant areas reap the benefits from increased tourism and those immediately under the flight path are those who bear an unequalled share of the costs.

PARA.TAB: The second point which I think should be stressed—and Senator Margetts mentioned it earlier—is that in this bill we see the application of a principle which should be applied more generally. They are the factors which economists call the externalities—that is, the real costs which do not appear in the bottom line of the program which is causing those costs to be generated.

Those costs do not appear in that bottom line. Those costs are not borne by the beneficiaries of the process, the factory or whatever but they are borne elsewhere in the economy. Those real costs are borne elsewhere. They are called externalities which need to be internalised, which is the proper economic system. Clearly, that means the application by government of a tax on those operations and the hypothecation of that tax to those who are affected, those who bear the costs.

This is a point that I have made very often, particularly in relation to sales tax: sales tax should be used as a process by which the externalities are internalised and the proper costs of the product are seen by the consumers. Therefore, rational discussions are made in relation to the consumption of those goods or services and those who are external to the generation of the cost nonetheless bear those costs so those people can be adequately compensated.

Here we have one of those rare examples of a situation in which the government has seen that this is a way of internalising, at least partially, those externalities. So those who generate the aircraft noise pay the increased levy and those who suffer the imposition of that noise, those who are under the flight path, can to some extent be compensated. That is a principle that the government is accepting in this legislation. It is a principle that should receive much wider application.

If I could just reflect for a moment on one of the points that was made by Senator Margetts, who was referring to the need to supply forced ventilation to those houses that will be extensively insulated. I was surprised and rather dismayed to hear her say that that type of forced ventilation will mean a replacement of the air inside the house every 30 minutes, and that that will necessarily involve very large energy bills. I will be absolutely dismayed if the government seeks to impose that very simple solution, very unsatisfactory solution, on those people under the flight path.

There are already very effective countercurrent heat exchanger devices which would allow one, say, in winter time to bring fresh air into the house and extract the heat from the warm air going out of the house in a countercurrent heat exchanger so that the heat inside the house was preserved but fresh air was brought in; similarly, in the summer time to maintain the coolness inside the house and exchange that coolness with warm air coming in, nonetheless bringing in fresh air. So if the government has not looked at this—and I have not been part of the Senate committee looking at it—I strongly urge it to do so.

The Australian Democrats will not be opposing the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill and the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill, which are being debated this afternoon. As has already been noted in the debate on these bill, the purpose of this legislation is to impose a levy on jet aircraft landings at airports where a federally funded noise amelioration package is in place and when certain criteria have been met.At present, the only airport where any sort of noise package is in place is at Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport where the new third runway has caused intolerable levels of noise and distress for thousands of residents in noise affected suburbs.

Much has been said in recent months about the reasons why the noise problems at Sydney have caused such distress. I know from my parliamentary colleague Senator Vicki Bourne, as I mentioned on whose behalf I am giving this speech this afternoon, that the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney, of which she is a member, has received submissions and heard evidence from some extremely distressed people who have had their lives almost destroyed by the noise from aircraft flying overhead.

One important point that does need to be made in today's debate is that, in most cases, residents affected by airport noise had absolutely no idea whatsoever that the aircraft noise was going to be such a problem in the areas where they are living. The Australian Democrats believe that the biggest cause for concern here is that the residents of Sydney were not properly informed as to the noise impact arising from the third runway becoming operational. If I could interpolate there, I think there was an enormous degree of misleading information, inadequate collection and wrong interpretation of data, which has led to that imposition of the noise on the people of Sydney.

To say that the information provided by the government, and in particular by the CAA, was less than adequate is itself something of a major understatement, as I have just indicated. Such behaviour on behalf of a government agency in the case of the CAA is totally unacceptable. We find it remarkable that the CAA chose to behave in such a manner before and, indeed, since the new runway has been operational.

If there is one conclusion which can be drawn from all this, it is that the community reaction to the new flight paths was seriously underestimated by the original environmental impact statement on the third runway. Even calling this an EIS is perhaps something of a misnomer. Senators will have noted that we are proposing an additional amendment to the opposition's second reading attachment. I understand, from words recently with Senator Parer, that the opposition is supporting those additional clauses.

What seems to have been the biggest failure was the absolute deficiency in the use of the Australian noise exposure forecast system, or the ANEF as it is called. The ANEF system did not correctly predict the noise impact, and this point has been emphasised again and again to the select committee. The weakness of the EIS is hardly surprising when one considers just how flawed and biased the process was. You cannot realistically expect the proponent of the project to then turn around and write an objective assessment of the environmental impacts arising from the third runway.

Is it any wonder that affected residents are upset and angry? Not only were they misinformed and deceived, but their lives have in some cases now been totally ruined by the noise from aircraft flying overhead. They feel they have been betrayed by the government. In fact, an objective assessment would say not only do they feel themselves betrayed by the government but they have been betrayed by the government.

Accordingly, as I mentioned, the Democrats will be moving a second reading amendment at the conclusion of this debate to note the failure of the government's EIS process which, as we noted earlier, is largely responsible for the outright deception the people of Sydney have suffered in this whole sorry mess. Indeed, it is imperative at this time, as we focus on the failure of the EIS to accurately predict noise impact, that the government provides a commitment to the parliament and the residents living in the surrounds of the new Sydney West airport that the same mistakes will not be repeated.

The EIS on the Sydney West airport must be a genuine and thorough process, carried out independently and at arms length from the aviation bureaucracy and guaranteed to produce positive outcomes in accurately predicting the impact on the people of western Sydney. This aspect forms the second part of the Democrats's second reading amendment.

Since this issue blew up in the government's face, Senator Bourne tells me that her office has been flooded with letters and phone calls from people whose lives have been totally ruined by the aircraft noise. I know that other senators and members have had a similar experience. Our amendment today seeks to reflect those concerns of the affected residents.

The third part of our amendment picks up on the concern which has been voiced only this week and relates to the government's intentions to privatise both Kingsford Smith and the Sydney West airports. Many residents quite rightly fear what is involved in the government's privatisation agenda and have expressed the concern that any moves towards this agenda at that particular time would represent extremely bad timing on the government's part.

The airport privatisation issue forms an important aspect of the Senate select committee's terms of reference, and the Democrats believe that it would be far more appropriate for the government to await the committee's findings and recommendations in this area before proceeding with any legislation on privatisation. This would certainly go some way in allaying growing community concern about the government's privatisation agenda.

The Democrats also remain concerned that the measures contained in this legislation will not be sufficient to deal with the ongoing noise problem at Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport. The reality is that under the measures contained in these bills, thousands of affected residents will not qualify for sound proofing. The criteria under which one qualifies is simply too strict. I think Senator Margetts developed that theme quite well in her speech a few moments ago.

I understand that already the select committee has received submissions and heard from many people who are adversely affected by noise impact but most of them do not qualify for soundproofing. Senator Parer made these same points during his speech in the debate on these bills. It would not be unreasonable to assume that people who have taken the time to make a submission before the committee are themselves a fair representation of the thousands who are currently suffering unreasonable levels of aircraft noise but who will not qualify for the relief measures contained in these bills.

As well, there is the question of the effectiveness of the soundproofing being provided, doubts about which have already been raised and which suggest the possibility that this will simply not be the nice, easy solution to noise which some people may think is provided for in these bills. For instance, in its submission to the committee the coalition of 12 local councils most affected by aircraft noise showed that areas as widespread as Bundeena and Cronulla in the south to Turramurra, Pymble and Chatswood in the north are currently experiencing aircraft noise levels totally disruptive to ordinary daily living; and yet not one of these suburbs was ever identified as likely to be adversely affected by aircraft noise in the period before the third runway became operational.

Therefore, there is every likelihood that the noise problem in Sydney will get much worse for a great many more people when and if the new control tower becomes fully operational. Once this happens, the CAA will allow a substantial increase in the hourly rate of aircraft movements to more than 80 per hour, whereas I understand that the current level is around 60 aircraft movements per hour. One can only try and imagine how much worse the noise will become when this is allowed to happen, given that the noise in affected suburbs is already at intolerable levels.

It is also forecast that some areas presently unaffected in Drummoyne, Hunters Hill and Lilyfield will be affected by aircraft noise for the first time, while suburbs already badly affected such as Lane Cove, Balmain, Leichhardt and Erskineville will be subject to louder and more frequent noise levels. All this will only serve to underscore the inadequacy of the insulation and soundproofing eligibility criteria contained in these bills. The Democrats believe that there is an urgent need for legislation to freeze the rate of aircraft movement.

One final point that needs to be made in relation to these bills is that funds raised from the proposed aircraft levy contained in these bills are clearly earmarked for the specific purpose of noise amelioration. The Democrats believe that the government should apply this principle, known as hypothecating, in other similar circumstances so that revenues can be raised for specific purposes rather than ending up in consolidated revenue. That is the point that I stressed right at the beginning. Most operations are accompanied by externalities which impact on people and on the environment. They must be internalised. One way in which the government can do this is to amplify this particular measure into other areas; to raise taxes in one form or another and to hypothecate those taxes in the amelioration of the costs.

This will mean, of course, that there will be a greater capacity for funds to be raised for specific projects, such as levies particularly, say, in transport related areas. One which, hopefully, we will be dealing with later in this session is the question of the increased revenue from a tax on various fuels, including diesel fuel and light fuel used by rail. It would be ideal if that were hypothecated to building up the rail system which has been allowed to run down very significantly since 1983.

While the Democrats support the measures contained in this legislation, we doubt that it will be sufficient to deal with the growing noise problem in Sydney. The Democrats' amendment is to be added to the end of Senator Parer's amendment. On behalf of Senator Bourne and the Democrats I now move:
At the end of the motion, add:
"and the Senate
(c) notes the absolute failure of the Government's Environment Impact Statement process to adequately predict the aircraft noise impact on the residents of Sydney;

(d) calls on the Government to ensure that the Environment Impact Statement process is revamped with the view to ensuring that the same errors are not committed in relation to the Sydney West Airport; and

(e) urges the Government to delay the introduction of all legislation dealing with the privatisation of Sydney's airports until such times as the Senator Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney has reported on this matter to the Senate".

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks about the specifics of the legislation and I also want to take issue with a few of the remarks made by Senator Parer and Senator Macdonald in this debate. Firstly, the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill 1995 is a landmark bill. It establishes for the first time in this country a regime whereby the principle that the polluter pays will be applied to ensure that amelioration is provided to communities affected by aircraft noise.

PARA.TAB: The bill establishes the important principle that as airlines and their passengers are the major beneficiaries of an airport's operations they should in turn be required to meet the costs of reducing the more severe impacts on the affected communities in the vicinity of airports. The purposes of the bill are to provide for the imposition of a levy on jet aircraft landings at airports where noise amelioration programs are being funded by the federal government.

To date, a major program has been commenced in Sydney and the government has already announced its intention to introduce, following detailed scoping studies, similar schemes at Adelaide and Coolangatta airports in the future. In Sydney the program provides for the voluntary acquisition of 113 homes in the 40 ANEF contours and to provide for sound insulation to some 4,300 homes above the 30 ANEF contours and sound insulation of schools, colleges, child-care facilities, hospitals, health-care facilities and churches within the 25 ANEF area. The estimated cost of the Sydney program is some $260 million. The scope of the eligibility for this program is at least equal to and in most respects exceeds that of any other major airport in the world where a noise amelioration program is in place.

The important point that needs to be recognised is that it is this Labor government that is doing something about the problems of aircraft noise, particularly in the Sydney region. It is a Labor government that is committed to building a new airport at Badgerys's Creek.

Last week in my condolence speech with respect to Fred Daly I referred to the fact that when Fred was the member for Grayndler as far back as 1953 he was raising in this parliament the problem of aircraft noise as it impacted upon the residents of his electorate and of surrounding electorates in the St George, Kogarah, Arncliffe and Rockdale regions. It has only ever been Labor members of this parliament and Labor members of the New South Wales parliament who have expressed real concern about the impact of aircraft noise on the residents of Sydney. One can point to a long line of Labor MPs, be they Leo McLeay, Gary Punch, Jeanette McHugh and the Minister for Transport, Laurie Brereton, who have continually raised concerns about the impact of aircraft noise from Kingsford Smith airport.

The campaign to have the third runway built at Sydney airport was vigorously supported by members of the Liberal and National parties. This government has had the courage to confront the issue of endeavouring to find a way through the competing interests of the needs of the travelling public who utilise aircraft and the needs of the economic considerations of having an international airport located in or near Sydney. This government is committed to finding a balance between those interests and the interests of the residents who live in close proximity to the airport or underneath the flight path. This government has had the courage to tackle that issue.

I listened intently to Senator Parer and Senator Sandy Macdonald last night, who are members of the select committee, as they attempted to criticise the federal Labor government on this issue and moved this quite ridiculous and hypocritical amendment seeking to condemn the government with respect to aircraft noise. What has been the record of the Liberal and National parties on this issue? Let us have a look at what their record is. Let us look at the statements made by those who were beating the drum most loudly in promotion of the third runway.
Let us look firstly to the now Leader of the Opposition, John Howard. What did he say on 21 March 1989 in an interview with Mike Carlton on 2GB? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I grew up under the flight paths in the St George area of Sydney and know something about the politics of that area and I've always regarded the issue as being grossly exaggerated in terms of the impact on the local residents. There are a limited number of people who are severely affected by aircraft noise. The great bulk of them are only mildly affected and in any event bought their houses knowing full well that they were under flight paths. In any event there are many sections of my electorate in areas like Lane Cove and Hunters Hill that have just as much aircraft noise and are as frequently under flight paths as people living near the airport.
Mike Carlton intervened and said:
They may in fact get less if the third runway is built—people around Lane Cove.
John Howard replied:

Many people will because you'll have the north-south pattern. I think the case for it on general interest grounds is absolutely overwhelming . . . Our policy is to build it. That has been our policy for the past six and a half years.

TALK.START.PARA: —No EIS.

—No EIS, no consideration of safety—just reopen the east-west runway. Let us see what Senator Parer, the chairman of this inquiry, had to say about these issues. The report compiled by the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure in December 1988 dealt with the adequacy of international terminal and aircraft handling facilities at Sydney airport. Senator Parer, along with Senator Chapman and Senator Boswell, issued a dissenting report.

PARA.TAB: The majority of that committee were in favour of promoting the development of a new airport in Sydney rather than constructing a third runway.
