The most important justification for a parallel runway is the dramatic improvement it would provide in bad weather. It would also halve the number of noise affected residents.

SPEECH.PARA: They go on in 1.35:

PARA.TAB: From the evidence gathered from representatives of the aviation industry and views expressed by key personnel, we believe a third runway must be commenced without delay and that time be the essence of the contract.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what Senator Parer and other spokespersons for the Liberal and National parties are on the record as saying with respect to the third runway—`Get it built. Get it built as quickly as possible because it is going to halve aircraft noise.'

PARA.TAB: One can go on. One can quote David Jull's press release of 1 October 1991 in which he urged the government to ignore the advice of the New South Wales opposition leader Bob Carr and order the immediate commencement of Sydney's third runway. He said in September 1990:

SPEECH.PARA: Environmental and general public concerns must be balanced against the indispensable economic role played by Mascot and the widely accepted fact that construction of an alternative facility at Badgerys Creek provides no solution to the problem at Sydney airport.
He went on in October 1991 to say:
The critics of the EIS are acting like spoilt children.
They now stand up and say, `The EIS process was flawed and people were misled about aircraft noise.'

TALK.START.PARA: —John Howard is a spoilt child?
—Yes. What did Mr Alan Cadman say in January 1991? He branded the opponents of the third runway as short-sighted. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than see the irrefutable merits of the third runway, they have put self interest before Australia's long-term national interests, and they are jeopardising the long-term safety of travellers.

The people who were opposing this third runway construction—the residents and the councils—were accused of putting self-interest before Australia's long-term national interests. Now these same people stand up here and claim to be their champions. Gary Nehl, the member for Cowper, said in February 1989:
A third runway would increase the airport's capacity by as much as 40 percent and significantly ease congestion and safety worries . . .
He gave a cast-iron guarantee that a third runway would be built if the coalition came to power. Remember Charles Blunt?

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Party does.
—The post office remembers him, that's for sure. Charles Blunt said in December 1988:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party is trying to hold back the tide—
because the Labor Party had strong reservations about constructing this runway—
Their opposition to a third runway is not only stupid it is untenable.
The capacity of Kingsford Smith Airport is stretched to the limit. Labor is putting not only economic growth at risk, but also the safety of air travellers.

Safety was an issue. Why was safety an issue? Safety was an issue because Sydney airport was operating with cross runways; with planes taking off and landing on both the east-west and the north-south runways. There was clearly always a risk of a major collision on the ground—something that very nearly happened on two occasions in the early 1990s.

PARA.TAB: Safety was clearly an important issue and these opposition spokespersons are on record as saying two things: first, that the construction of a third runway would reduce aircraft noise and its impact upon people. And on the numbers it has actually done that. The number of people now affected by aircraft noise is significantly less because of the closure or downgrading of the east-west runway, but it has also recognised that the impact upon that lesser number of people is actually greater because of the more frequent use of the north-south runway.

Don't let these pious hypocrites come in here, stand up and say that the government misled the people. The fact of the matter is that Senator Parer, John Howard, the Leader of the Opposition, and Nick Greiner, the former Premier of New South Wales, were all out there beating the drum, urging the government to build this third runway—`Don't worry about EISs. Get in and build it.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are they now?
—Yes, where are they now?
—Who made the decision?

—Who made the decision? I see: all care, no responsibility—is that it? It is probably no care and no responsibility when it comes to your policies, Senator Parer. But the minister has made it abundantly clear that safety is a critical factor in this whole issue.

PARA.TAB: We have John Howard, the Leader of the Opposition, and others out there saying, `The simple solution to this problem is reopening the east-west runway and dumping more than half of that aircraft noise back on the residents who live under the flight path of the east-west runway'—residents, of course, who were never cared about by a succession of Liberal governments in either the federal or the state parliament, residents who John Howard himself criticised by saying, `They grossly exaggerate the problem.' So, when it was under the old east-west runway, it was never really a problem; but now somehow it is a problem because the residents of Bennelong have taken up the issue with John Howard and have condemned him for his hypocrisy on this issue.

The issue of safety is a very important one. The minister has indicated that, on the basis that the operation of the two parallel runways is a safer operation than returning to the old SIMOPS operations or to the use of the cross runways, the east-west runway will not be reopened. What we find in this debate is a cynical attempt by the opposition to use safety, when it completely contradicts the facts and the propositions that they advanced back when they were so strongly supporting the third runway. Let us look at some of the comments the opposition made about safety when they were arguing that the third runway should be built. In December 1988, John Sharp said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is ignoring the safety hazard the present chaotic conditions are presenting.
What was this chaos? It was this increasing congestion at Sydney airport through having to use cross runways. That was the safety problem—having to use cross runways.

PARA.TAB: Now that the government has implemented a situation where it is actually safer to land or to take off from Sydney airport because of the utilisation of the parallel runways, the opposition turn around and say, `Let's ignore all that. Let's ignore those safety concerns that we had back in 1988 and 1989. Let's just reopen the east-west runway.' It is a politically cynical exercise based simply upon the fact that they do not like the residents in Hunters Hill and in Lane Cove complaining to them, because they supported the construction of the third runway. Tim Fischer said in August 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: Any further delay in deciding on the third runway for Mascot could mean loss of life as well as economic insanity.

In September 1991, David Jull renewed his call for the third runway project to commence following a near collision involving a Qantas B747 landing at Mascot. That is what the opposition said at the time: `We've got these safety concerns. We've had these near incidents, these near collisions. Let's remove those problems caused by intersecting runways. Let's get this third runway built.' The third runway gets built; the minister brings about a safer operation at Sydney airport; and Senator Parer stands up in this Senate and condemns the government for closing the east-west runway. What sheer hypocrisy!

PARA.TAB: Then those opposite have the gall to move this amendment to say that the government misled the people. The people who are doing the misleading in this entire debate are the opposition spokespersons, who are trying to give false comfort to the residents of Sydney affected by aircraft noise by pretending to them that we can just simply reopen the east-west runway with a click of the finger without consideration for the environmental impacts and without consideration for the obvious reduction in safety.

This debate will go on as the committee continues undertaking its deliberations and taking evidence from the various parties appearing before it. But the government is committed to ensuring that the residents affected by the operations of Kingsford Smith airport obtain the most possible relief from aircraft noise. The government are not going to ignore those residents, like the opposition did for years and years when they were in government. We are not going to ignore them, like the previous Liberal government did when they so callously got out there and led the charge to support the runway construction.

When Labor councils, Labor members of parliament and residents of those communities said that there would be aircraft noise problems, they were laughed at by the opposition. But those predictions, of course, have been shown to be true. It is this government that is doing something about solving these problems, by passing this Aircraft Noise Levy Bill which brings about the opportunity to insulate these homes, schools and hospitals and so on and by fast-tracking the construction of the Badgerys Creek airport as a long-term solution. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would like to thank the various speakers who have contributed to this debate on the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill and the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill. Clearly, the government does not agree with the position as enunciated by opposition, Green or Democrat senators. I would particularly like to congratulate Senator Forshaw for his contribution. While I have not followed this issue in as detailed a way as he has, the variety of positions that opposition spokespersons have had on this issue over the last seven or eight years is quite astounding—and it is on the record for all to see.

PARA.TAB: In fact, I can recall going to tourism conferences when Mr Jull was opposition spokesperson on tourism and I can recall him making all sorts of comments—Senator Forshaw has quoted some of them—about the need to fast-track the third runway at Sydney airport, to get on with it, and condemning the government for not doing it quickly enough. We have had comments from Mr Blunt—we do not need to talk about what happened to him—as well as from Messrs Fischer, Nehl, Parer and Howard; we have got an amazing range of comments on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —And there's more to come!

—I am sure Senator Forshaw could have gone on for hours if he had had the time to in this debate. We have got an opposition led by Mr Howard talking about honesty and integrity and truthfulness in policy. I have never heard such a set of contradictory positions from any opposition in any debate during my five years in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The debate on these bills has produced a predictable range of views about the impact of the construction of the parallel runway at Sydney airport. Much of the debate has focused on the decision and rationale to restrict operations on the east-west runway. The closure of the east-west runway, except in adverse weather conditions, was an integral part of the government's decision to construct the parallel runway. The government maintains that parallel runway operations are ultimately the best way of getting high safe movement rates through the airport. There has also been little recognition in the debate about the significant number of people in Sydney who have benefited from restricting the use of the east-west runway.

I should also point out that the noise management plan is not, as Senator Parer implied, a belated reaction to the problem of aircraft noise in Sydney. The development of the plan was an integral part of the government's decision on the construction of the new runway. The only belated position in all of this, Senator Parer, is your position and that of various opposition spokespersons on this issue over the last five or six years—as has been so well illustrated by Senator Forshaw. The plan necessarily took some time to complete, so it was not possible to commence an insulation and acquisition program before the runway opened. There are two main reasons for that: the extensive process of consultation that was built into the development of the plan, and the fact that nothing of this kind has ever been attempted in Australia before.

Senator Parer also raised doubts about the final costs of the program. The current estimate of the cost of the program is based on the best information currently available about what is a very large and complex undertaking. It is not valid to compare the current estimate of $260 million with the indicative figures originally contained in the draft noise management plan. Such a comparison fails to recognise the broader scope of the program compared with the draft plan and also the more detailed knowledge of insulation costs that has been gained over the intervening period.

Certainly, the three-year target for completing the residential insulation program represents a challenge. There is clearly a need for industry to gear itself up to undertake the task. The government believes that the target of completing the program within three years is achievable. It will be doing all it can to ensure that the time frame is met. The people in Sydney that are impacted by aircraft noise deserve no less.

As Senator Parer has flagged, there will doubtless be problems encountered in insulating particular buildings to acceptable internal noise levels. The type of work being undertaken is new to Australia. Much has been learned in the work to date, including the pilot study, which will stand us in good stead in meeting those challenges as they arise.

Turning to some other matters, Senator MacGibbon suggested that the government should be enforcing the use of quieter aircraft, and in particular that Ansett should be forced to withdraw its B727 and F28 aircraft. The phase-out of these aircraft is in fact already being pursued. The opposition would just say, overnight, `Look; let's get rid of these aeroplanes out of the air; let's just get rid of them'—regardless of the disruption to the Ansett and Qantas fleet arrangements.

Consistent with international agreements, existing Chapter 2 aircraft, such as the B727 and the F28, must be withdrawn from use or modified to reduce noise levels by 1 March 2002. It would be a massive commercial cost—and I do not know what the figures are—to just say, as the opposition say, `Let's get rid of these planes', regardless of the millions of dollars that have been spent on the aircraft—`Let's just get rid of them out of the air tomorrow'. What a grossly irresponsible position!

Senator MacGibbon also mentioned the need for better land use planning around airports. Currently the development of land surrounding airports is largely a matter for state and local government planning processes. The government believes there is a need to seek better outcomes and is working in conjunction with the states towards developing a more integrated planning approach. Transport ministers are due to consider the outcomes of work by officials on this matter later this year. The government is concerned to ensure that the impact of airports on their surrounding communities is minimised and will continue to pursue measures to ensure that this is the case. These bills are part of that. They provide for the first time a mechanism of recovering the costs imposed by aircraft noise from the aircraft that generate the problem.

There are two other matters. Firstly, the government will be opposing amendments (a) and (b) as circulated by Senator Parer, and those to be amended by Senator Bourne containing new (c), (d) and (e). I note that subclause (e) urges the government to delay the introduction of all legislation dealing with the privatisation of Sydney airports until such time as the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney has reported on this matter to the Senate. I do not know how many Senate select committees we have operating at the moment—the numbers have certainly gone up since I came here five years ago—but if we were to act in this manner and delay consideration of legislation until the outcome of every select committee that comes along—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just because it is inquiring into it. How outrageous!

—Really, Senator; you can't be serious. Goodness knows there have been a lot of Senate select committees in our time, in the five years you and I have been here in this chamber. Governments just cannot wait around for all of these committees to complete their work.
—What an extraordinary argument, Nick. You've lost your mind.

—Really! Senator Bourne, you might be interested in this quote. Who said these words—speaking through you, Mr Acting Deputy President—`They grossly exaggerate the problem'? Who said those words? It was the current Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. He said those words six years ago when he was urging the government to build the third runway. As I said at the beginning of my speech, where are we in terms of consistency, truthfulness and integrity of policy development when we have an opposition leader who adopts this amazing U-turn, along with almost the entire frontbench of the current opposition?

PARA.TAB: I urge the Senate to pass the legislation speedily. I commend the bills. I think the amendments have been moved compositely by Senator Parer and the Democrats, and obviously we can add the numbers together. We will not be calling a division in the interests of saving time, but I, for the record, just state that obviously we do not support the amendments that have been moved by the opposition and the Democrats. I would urge every senator—and all those people listening to this debate—to read Senator Forshaw's contribution on this matter.
Amendment (Senator Coulter's) agreed to.
Amendment (Senator Parer's), as amended, agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

The bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are debating the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill and the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill as a whole, I would like to make a few comments in response to Senator Forshaw and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry). Senator Forshaw talked about hypocrisy. If ever I have heard hypocrisy, I heard it from Senator Forshaw. He got up here and talked about all those good Labor people who oppose the building of what he called the third runway. In fact, it is the half runway. We had two runways before, another runway was built, so we now have one and a half. What an incredible exercise!

PARA.TAB: Senator Forshaw talked about all those people and about how they had gone to the barricades. Do you know what happened? Do you know who made the decision to build it? The government made the decision to build it after saying, for years and years, they would not have a bar of another runway. People bought properties on that basis, and then the government made the decision. Why did they make the decision? They made it because apparently they had some sort of sleazy deal which meant if they built this runway they would shut off what was traditionally the original jet strip at Sydney. Apparently it was done simply to protect electorates. So the decision-making process had nothing to do with safety.

Senator Forshaw talked about safety, as did Senator Sherry. They kept saying that safety was the critical factor. From what I understand, from talking with people who were involved in the CAA in those days, safety was not considered. Senator Forshaw was good at quoting people. On 13 August 1991, in response to a question from Senator Brownhill about the near miss that everyone is aware of that had occurred in Sydney—and near misses are occurring today, I might say, notwithstanding the new runway configuration—Senator Bob Collins, who was the then minister, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are that simultaneous operations are in operation at many, many major airports around the world. There is absolutely no reason whatever why simultaneous operations, if conducted efficiently and professionally, cannot be used—as they are used in Adelaide, as well as Sydney—with perfect safety.
They are the words of the then minister. No doubt the information had been provided to him—I am sure he would not have said it off the cuff—by the then Civil Aviation Authority.

PARA.TAB: Senator Forshaw also referred to a dissenting report in 1988 to which I was a party. I totally agree with the words in that report. We talked about the immediate construction of the parallel runway. He quoted me as saying that it was `to halve the number of noise-affected residents'. That is quite correct. It is important to know where the new runway was to be located. It was to be located south of the east-west runway, which is now closed, and east of the main north-south runway, which meant that aircraft in the main would take off or land from the south. This would have taken the pressure not only off the people in the northern parts of Kingsford-Smith Airport but also off the people east and west.

The important thing to remember is that, when that report was written, there was no indication whatsoever that the east-west would be shut. Senator Collins was one member on that committee, and I can remember very well that all of the evidence given to the committee indicated that that extra runway should be built for two reasons. One was to increase the capacity but the other, more importantly, was to halve the noise problems that already existed in Sydney. Notwithstanding the evidence given to that committee, because it was then policy not to build the darn thing, the Labor Party came out with a majority report saying they should not build it but they should perhaps look at it some time down the track. I made the point when debating that particular report that, in view of the fact that all these people had given evidence in good faith and at great cost to them, the evidence was not taken into account at all when the majority report came down. I recall saying very well that, if that was to occur in the future, these committees would be a waste of time.

The point that has to be made is that, when that recommendation in the minority report came in, the intent was not to close the east-west runway. As has been said by many people, as that committee has not concluded its evidence, I do not think it is proper to pre-empt its findings. But the point has been made over and again by pilots, by air traffic controllers—people who should know as they are the ones who use the airport—that the east-west can be opened safely. Whether you use simultaneous operations can be debated, but there is a system called dependent use of crossing runways. It is used in major airports all around the world. I think it is important that this differentiation be made, notwithstanding the remarks by air traffic controllers, the pilots and the Civil Aviation Authority that it is less safe. I do not think anyone would dispute that. But when the question was asked `How less safe?' the answer could not be given. Someone said to me that it was very similar to using crossroads with lights or a roundabout.

It is important that I put that on the record because Senator Forshaw had the gall to come in here and talk about hypocrisy. If ever there was hypocrisy, it is from Labor people who are saying, `Look at me, aren't I pure? I objected.' Who made the decision to go ahead and do it? It was the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were doing what you wanted us to do.

—I think Senator Sherry made some remarks that the reason they did it was that we encouraged them. How weak can you be! You cannot escape that easily, Senator Sherry. This government has inflicted on thousands and thousands of innocent people a noise problem that they did not have before. That is totally inequitable and it supports the view in the community as a whole that this government has lost touch and is not interested in listening to people.

PARA.TAB: A cursory glance at some of the 3,500 submissions that the select committee has would indicate the people's gratefulness for this committee being set up. As they said, all their efforts to convey their concerns to the government had fallen on deaf ears and this was their last hope. As Senator Bourne would recall, that has been said to us over and again, and it has come from a whole range of people. It has come from people in suburbs that the Labor Party would call their Labor heartland—Leichhardt/Marrickville. People feel that they have been abused by the government on this issue. It comes from people who had no indication of this whatsoever, hence our agreement to support the Democrat amendment and their supporting of our amendment. Those people were not given information that enabled them to make decisions about where they lived and how they lived.

The government will not escape from this issue. Any ideas they might have that this problem will go away would indicate that they have totally and utterly lost touch with the people. They are seen to be a government which could not care less about the effect of their decisions on the ordinary Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity to make some comments on and ask some questions about the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill 1995. The opening of the third runway, as Senator Parer said, basically concluded that Sydney would have 1 1/2 runways when it was promised three. It has 1 1/2 runways when it was promised three because the new parallel runway is used only for landings from the north and landings from the south but take-offs to the south were prohibited and the east-west runway was closed. The east-west runway was closed solely because of politics, not because of safety. As Senator Parer said, originally when the decision to build the third runway was taken, we have it on very good authority that safety was not even considered.

PARA.TAB: I move now to the decision to embark on noise insulation. We are told that noise insulation is provided for houses over 30 ANEF—which is the Australian noise enforcement forecast—and schools and similar buildings, such as nursing homes and hospitals, over 25 ANEF. But there has been no undertaking to insulate public buildings. There are a number of public buildings in the flight path, including the Marrickville town hall, where we took evidence. I would like to know why that decision was not taken and why it would not be appropriate to provide some insulation to those public buildings.

I also make the point that the ANEF contours have absolute suspect credibility. The whole EIS process was suspect. The ANEF method of determination of noise seems to be totally inappropriate. I understand that it is based on the logarithmic table, and it takes a completely inappropriate view. Apparently, if you have an area that is subject to 20 ANEF and you double the traffic, it is possible that the ANEF might only go to 23, which seems an extraordinarily unfair real approach to the impact of aircraft noise. To be fair the government must have a very close look at the way the ANEF contours work, the areas covered and the credibility of that assessment process.

I would like to know whether the government proposes to provide compensation or to review its noise insulation program for those houses that are presently outside the ANEF guidelines. There are a number of problems not only with the original EIS but also with the method of determining what noise level people affected in Sydney are feeling.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in the committee stage of this bill, principally to correct one of the gross misrepresentations that was made by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) when he was summing up the bill. I was working in my office and, because the Labor Party was speaking, I had the sound switched off. I finished what I was doing and I switched on and heard this travesty of the truth coming from the parliamentary secretary.

PARA.TAB: I appreciate you have impaired comprehension, Senator Sherry, but I did not say in the debate that I was going to sell all the aircraft that were operating into Sydney airport. What I did say—and I will say it in as close to monosyllabic words as possible so you can follow it—was that the oldest aircraft were the noisiest. They were the Boeing 727s and the Fokker F28s. I said they were almost totally written off against the books of the company that was operating them and I was surprised that the government did not suggest to the company that they conform to the accepted noise standards for aircraft operating in RPT services. It was really a gross misrepresentation to claim that I said anything to the contrary.

The other point is that you, Senator, implied that I did not realise that land planning around airports was a matter for the state government and local councils. I understand that very well, but I also understand the power of the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth is inter alia—through the FAC—the owner of those airports. If there is vacant land on the approach paths and that is in the beady eyes of the Labor council of Brisbane to be converted into a high density residential area, presumably with housing commission houses where they can put a few more Labor voters in—although it would not help them much because it is a Labor area—then it would have been possible for the Commonwealth government, if it had any intelligence and foresight, to have gently suggested to the Brisbane City Council and the state government that there were better places to build houses than on the old Cannon Hill saleyards. And with that I rest.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to the last contribution, we had the usual trite comments from you, Senator MacGibbon, on a personal basis. If you happened to have the TV on, well, big deal. If you want to embellish your comments with personal comments, that is up to you. It is a sad reflection on your approach to a very serious issue.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the matter raised by Senator Sandy Macdonald, insulation of public buildings, I understand that the recommendation from the working group set up by the FAC for the insulation of various buildings—I do not know its precise title—did not include a recommendation for public buildings. It did include nursing homes, hospitals, child-care centres and schools. That is not an exhaustive list, but I think it is indicative of the buildings that will be insulated. We have taken the position that we would act on those recommendations. However, the minister has said a further study will be conducted after three years with respect to residences below the 30 ANEF contour to further assess the application. I would emphasise that the noise treatment program will be the subject of continuous evaluation to ensure its objectives are met. It is not a static situation that we are dealing with.

Senator Parer makes a valiant attempt at defence by quoting the counter-quotes we have had across this chamber on this issue. I do not want to indulge in another speech in the second reading debate, so I just leave for the record once again the quote of—I will not say who it is; there are some new senators in here—a person who said, `They grossly exaggerate the problem.' This was said six years ago in reference to the possible problems emanating from the building of the third runway. That was said by the current Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard.

Senator Parer talked about a humane approach, a considered approach, an approach based on careful evaluation. All I can say is the current Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, has got a lot to learn. That was his position six years ago. His position today became clear when he appeared before the Senate committee—I saw it on TV. Mr Howard has done a 180-degree turn. Why? Obviously, political expediency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not continue that debate; we can have it another time. Clause 6 of the bill sets out the formula for collecting the levy. I would just like to ask what the levy unit will be for 1995-96.
—$155 per noise unit.

—I referred in the debate on the second reading—and the minister gave a response—to the fact that the actual final cost of the insulation program has slowly gone up and up. It started at $120 million, then went to $180 million; and it is now about $260 million—that was a couple of months ago. What is now the estimated final cost of the insulation program?
—Approximately $260 million.
—It might come back to haunt you, Minister. For how many years do you expect to have to impose the levy at Sydney airport?
—Approximately 10 years.
—How many homes has the government now purchased within the 40 ANEF contour at Sydney airport?
—43 out of 112?
—Out of 113.
—What is the status of the balance?

—The voluntary acquisition program for the 113 residential properties and one church within the 40 ANEF zone located north of the airport within part of Sydenham is well under way. At mid-August, 105 property owners have indicated interest in the offer. Sixty-one owners have agreed to sell and 43 residences have been acquired. A number of discussions have been held with representatives of the church and a suitable alternative site has been identified. The ultimate use of the area has not yet been determined. They are the reasons for the current pace of acquisition.
—How long do you expect the insulation program around the airport to take?
—Approximately three years.

—I understand, Minister, that if you go down the track of three years, which was the figure originally indicated, that would mean insulating a house every six hours. Are you going to meet that program?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand there are over 4,000 residences to be insulated.

—Yes. It will take some time for the insulation industry to gear up as it would have to. We believe, based on international comparisons, that the insulation industry should be able to achieve a figure of at least 100 per month. Clearly, the initial figure, on a monthly basis, is going to be lower than that and build up as the insulation companies acquire the appropriate staff and experience that is needed to accelerate the program.
—This would mean that the program will now stretch out to four years?

—I used the figure of a minimum of 100 per month based on international comparisons. We still believe that it is likely to take around three years. You cannot give a precise month or week on these sorts of issues. It will depend on the successful take-up by the insulation companies. But, as I say, based on international comparisons, we hope that the actual figure will be well in excess of 100. As the program builds up, we will see it achieved in the period that we have indicated—the three-year period.

—The Department of Administrative Services is carrying out a noise insulation pilot study. I would have thought you would really have no idea how long it would take to do that until that study had been completed. When will the report on the noise insulation pilot study be completed?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the report you refer to has gone to the minister this week. It will be up to the minister to release the report. As I said earlier, we do have international comparisons on this issue, so we can make some reasonable estimate of the time it will take, even without the report, based on international installations of insulation material.
—Are there any homes which, because of their structure, cannot be adequately insulated? If so, how many?

—There would be some homes. We cannot estimate the number at the moment because, clearly, that is going to be dependent on the people carrying out the insulation to those properties. That will be a significant factor and a judgment will need to be made by those people when that starts to happen. So we cannot give figures at the moment. But we do believe, again on the basis of comparative experience overseas, that there would be some properties that could not be successfully insulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on an environmental matter, namely the protection of the head waters of the Great Australian Bight, which has proved to be a very important breeding ground for the southern right whale. I do this because a great deal of concern has been expressed in South Australia in relation to a study which has been carried out jointly for both the Commonwealth and the state in relation to the designation of a marine park in that region. The reason for the joint study is that the three-mile limit comes under the state government's jurisdiction and the waters beyond that come under the Commonwealth's jurisdiction.

PARA.TAB: The report which has resulted from that study, which was jointly commissioned by both the Commonwealth and the state, is now being held by the state and not being released for public comment. It is not even being released, as I understand it, to the Commonwealth which was one of those requesting this report. So we have a situation where South Australia has, compared with the other states, very little of its waters designated as marine parks and the South Australian government appears to be resisting very vigorously and by rather dubious means the designation of the Great Australian Bight Marine Park.

By way of amplification let me say that Australia's marine environments are both diverse and unique, particularly in the southern temperate cold water regions. It is not generally recognised that the biodiversity in the colder parts of Australia is similar to or exceeds the biodiversity in the tropical areas. In the southern cooler temperate regions, a long period of geological isolation and a long east-west southern coastline have resulted in unparalleled diversity in many plant and animal groups.

For example, the southern waters of Australia have some of the highest levels of diversity for marine plants and invertebrates—that is, ascidians, bryozoans and crustaceans—in the world. These conditions have also resulted in many of these plants and animals being found nowhere else in the world. For instance, approximately 90 per cent of all fish, mollusc and echinoderms found in these cooler waters are found nowhere else in the world. In contrast, only 10 per cent of the tropical fauna is unique to the northern tropical regions of Australia.

The temperate southern regions of Australia are particularly poorly protected. Despite the very high levels of biodiversity, with many species found nowhere else in the world, more than 90 per cent of the area of Australia's marine parks is located in the tropical regions of Australia protecting tropical marine habitats. Approximately 88 per cent of the total area of marine parks in Australia comprises one marine park alone—that is, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Unfortunately, the marine habitats of the southern cooler regions of Australia are also under the greatest threat from human activities. It is the southern regions in which 75 per cent of Australia's population lives.

The Great Australian Bight Marine Park would be the first multiple-use marine park in the entire Greater Australian Bight region protecting the representative flora, fauna, habitats and ecosystems of the Great Australian Bight. To date, over 90 per cent of the present marine protected areas is in the tropical, relatively uninhabited regions of Australia. However, some of the highest levels of biodiversity and endemism occur in our temperate regions—they are also under the greatest pressure, as I indicated a moment ago, from human impact.

Marine parks are a nationally and internationally recognised tool for the integrated management of marine ecosystems, while conserving areas of key significance—that is, the Great Barrier Reef, Shark Bay, Ningaloo, et cetera. In all these parks only a small proportion, some five per cent to 10 per cent, is excluded from extractive or exploitative activities. The point I am stressing here is that these are multi-use areas which are designed to protect an overall area but within that to completely protect a small proportion, five per cent to 10 per cent, from those extractive or exploitative activities.

Marine parks are also wonderful ecotourism opportunities, as witnessed by the national and international profile of the reserves of the Great Barrier Reef, Shark Bay and Ningaloo. As such, the Great Australian Bight Marine Park has the potential to be a major national and international tourist drawcard for Australia, particularly for the remote west coast communities of South Australia. Indeed, during the present winter, very large numbers of people are visiting that area for whale watching.

South Australia is the only state in Australia not to declare any marine parks. Even many developing nations have marine parks, for instance Vietnam, Thailand and the Philippines. South Australia presently has the least proportional area of its jurisdictional waters protected under habitat conservation and management legislation. There is only 1.4 per cent in South Australia compared with 25 per cent and 20 per cent respectively in Queensland and Western Australia. The Western Australian government has recently released a report, the Wilson report, recommending a further 77 marine parks for its coastline. This is because of the demonstrated economic benefits, particularly ecotourism, of marine parks like Ningaloo and Shark Bay.

The Great Australian Bight Marine Park will protect one of the most critical nursery, calving and breeding areas of the endangered southern right whale in the world. It is also the most important site for carving and breeding in Australia—over half of all the calves born in Australian waters are born at this one site. This species is considered both threatened and vulnerable to extinction. The Great Australian Bight Marine Park is essentially multiple-use, managing a range of uses—that is, fishing, tourism, recreation, mining and conservation—on an integrated ecosystem basis.

The buffer zone proposed for the Great Australian Bight Marine Park is the conservation zone. Importantly, the proposed conservation zone will protect the activities of fishing and mining from detrimentally affecting the whales. Of particular concern is the potential for acoustic disturbance from boats and mineral exploration activities to cause disturbance to calving mothers.

Extensive research both here in Australia and overseas indicates that whales are affected by acoustic disturbance from boats from 27 kilometres away. That is an enormous distance and indicates the sensitivity of whales, particularly during this critical time of calving. The whales at the Head of Bight are calving mothers. The potential disturbance from adjacent boats can cause mothers to desert their calves and leave them prone to malnourishment and predation from white sharks. This has been identified as one of the major threats to the southern right whale and humpback whale populations in the Commonwealth's national cetacean action plan of 1995.

A proposed sanctuary—that is, the smaller area for complete protection—at the Head of Bight is not sufficient to protect the whales from acoustic disturbance. That is the alternative proposal being put by the South Australian government. That lesser proposal is being strongly promoted by some fishing interests and evidently also by the government of South Australia. Also the proposed Head of Bight sanctuary—that is, the smaller area proposed by the South Australian government—fails to protect the other critical breeding area at the Merdayerrah Sandpatch and also the migratory route between the two identified breeding areas.

Let us not forget the 21 breeding colonies of the rare Australian sea lions. These represent approximately 10 per cent of the world population and represent the most significant populations for this species in the world. This is because these species were never commercially harvested and hence are thought to have very high levels of genetic diversity, which is very important in the recovery of threatened or rare species.The Commonwealth of Australia has national and global responsibilities for protecting biodiversity and ensuring the sustainable use of resources, and also protecting rare and endangered marine mammals such as the endangered southern right whale and the rare Australian sea lion—that is, threatened species legislation and the national cetacean action plan, and the national seal action plan being drawn up by the Australian Nature Conservation Agency.
I see that I am going to run out of time. That is a convenient point at which to stop. I will continue my remarks tomorrow night.

PARA.TAB: School education (including curriculum planning, development and implementation) is the responsibility of State and Territory governments and non-government school authorities. The Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) does not maintain a data base on developments by State and Territory education authorities in specific subject areas. In that context, the best readily available information on the senator's questions is as follows.

(1) State and Territory Governments have responded to Recommendation 290 in collaboration with the Commonwealth to develop and implement Aboriginal Studies curricula within their respective education systems. This process is enhanced through State and Territory Strategic Plans under the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy.

(2) The Commonwealth is working with State and Territory governments to develop curriculum and resource materials for Aboriginal Studies. From 1989 to June 1993, the Commonwealth collaborated with States and Territories in the development of curriculum statements and profiles in eight "key learning areas". DEET funded the employment of consultants to ensure that the statements and profiles took account of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander perspectives. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies are identified as a major curriculum perspective for curriculum development within the key learning area of Studies of Society and Environment; this curriculum perspective is also reflected in other key learning areas. Development work is still taking place in these key learning areas. The Commonwealth has taken steps to encourage greater efforts in:
consistent Aboriginal Studies curricula for all schools across Australia from Year K-12;
development of consistent teacher education courses to promote greater sensitivity towards Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students;
establishment of a sister school scheme between Aboriginal and non Aboriginal schools;
a grassroots campaign to promote a greater understanding by students of their school areas' local Aboriginal communities and their histories; and
increasing the school community's capacity to research local Aboriginal history and inviting local Aboriginal people to support classroom activities.

Development work is still taking place in these areas. It is the responsibility of State and Territory Education Authorities to determine how subject areas are implemented within their education systems.

Through the Projects of National Significance Program the Commonwealth provided funds through DEET to support the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Project which supports the implementation of Recommendation 290. An objective of the program was to develop, through collaboration and consultation, projects to assist with curriculum development and facilitate implementation. These projects include:
(a) National Principles and Guidelines for Aboriginal Studies and Torres Strait Islander Studies

These Principles and Guidelines have been endorsed by the Federation of Aboriginal Education Consultative Groups and aim to help schools and school systems develop teaching and learning materials in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies so that students can be better informed about the history and lives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Fundamental to the Principles and Guidelines is the principle that local Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and organisations determine what is taught in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Studies and about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in schools.
The Principles and Guidelines were distributed to all schools free of charge in July 1995.
(b) Resource Guide for Aboriginal Studies and Torres Strait Islander Studies

This guide details numerous resources for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies available in Australia. It includes `selection criteria' for teachers and educators by which they can assess the appropriateness of teaching and learning materials in the context of the Principles and Guidelines.
(c) Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Teaching and Learning materials

These materials integrate with the `studies of society and environment' curriculum statement and profile and provide teaching and learning materials on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander studies in areas such as local history, culture, politics, religion, relationships with the land and human relationships. The materials embody the principles of local curriculum development. The material covers Years K-10 and are being developed under the auspices of the Curriculum Development Corporation which is owned by State and Territory governments. The materials are being monitored by Aboriginal Education Coordinators.

(3) Consistent with Constitutional responsibilities for education provision, DEET does not maintain a data base on State/Territory education authorities' developments in any subject area. However, the Commonwealth is aware that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies programs are currently being trialled by some education authorities with a view to receiving final accreditation. In the higher education sector all but the Northern Territory and South Australia currently have development programs in place. The expectation arising out of the provision of funds for these programs is that they will become part of the curriculum.

(4) Although DEET does not maintain a data base on State/Territory education authorities' developments in any subject area, the question of compulsory curriculum coverage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander perspectives is being considered by a Taskforce of the Commonwealth/State Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs (MCEETYA) which is examining recommendations of the National Review of Education for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples. That Review recommended, inter alia, that courses to improve non-indigenous Australians' understanding of and respect for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander traditional and contemporary cultures be made a mandatory element of the curricula of courses at all levels of education (Review recommendation 27). The Taskforce is to make a final report to MCEETYA on this and other Review recommendations later this year.

(5) The National Report on Schooling in Australia indicates that all State and Territories offer Aboriginal Studies at Year 12 (or equivalent) level as an accredited unit of work or as unaccredited work on a trial basis. The report highlights the efforts of both the Government and non-Government sectors in developing Aboriginal Studies curricula suitable for all levels of compulsory schooling.

(6) Non-government schools are included as part of the national education sector and can be involved in curriculum development processes along with State/Territory education authorities. Participation to date by non-government schools and peak bodies indicates their interest in Aboriginal Studies as part of their education program. However, as for government schools, the Commonwealth does not maintain a data base on non-government education authorities' developments in any subject area.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 28 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency established a research and development fund to encourage research directed at issues involving stormwater management, as recommended in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, Division of Water Resources consultancy report Urban Stormwater: Impacts on the Environment 1992; if so, how much funding has been allocated for this purpose; if not, why not.

(2) Has the Urban Water Research Association been allocated resources to coordinate and commission a data collection and analysis program directed at investigating the operation of stormwater and sewer networks in order to minimise cross contamination by overflows as recommended in the report; if so, what resources and or funding has been allocated; if not, why not.

(3) Have programs of research been commissioned and funded into the mechanisms of water quality improvement that occur in wetland and retardation basins, as recommended in the report; if so: (a) which organisations have been commissioned to do the research; (b) what time limits have they been given to complete the research; (c) what are the research objectives which have been given to these organisations; (d) how much funding has been allocated to this research; if not, why not

(4) Has funding for a commercially-viable version of the SIROFLOC process tailored to the treatment of sewage overflows at critical points in sewerage and stormwater networks been provided as recommended in the report; if so, how much funding has been allocated and what is the expected time of completion of this development; if not, why not.

(5) Has an advisory body been established and commissioned to suggest how appropriate arrangements can be implemented for the improved management of stormwater as recommended in the report; if so, has the advisory body made any recommendations and have the recommendations been acted on; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Research and development programs are not the primary role of the Environment Protection Agency. Urban stormwater is principally a State, Territory and Local Government responsibility in which the Commonwealth is limited in its capacity to be involved. Research work is being done through research organisations such as universities, CSIRO jointly with the Co-operative Research Centre for Waste Management and Pollution Control, and the Cooperative Research Centre for Fresh Water Ecology. The research has been looking into the mechanisms of water quality improvements that occur in wetland and retardation basins including:
mechanisms of natural wetlands in rural areas;
processes of wastewater treatments in constructed wetlands;
microbiology of nitrogen and phosphorus removal and disinfection in constructed wetlands;
large scale construction of wetlands, their design and performance criteria;
compact fast rate systems including new vertical flow designs;
SWAMP, a computer based system for the design and evaluation of constructed wetland systems.

The importance of wetland research is demonstrated by the timely Conference on Wetlands for Water Quality Control at the James Cook University, Townsville, Queensland in September. Topics to be covered include rural and urban runoff, design and modelling, wetlands for industrial effluents, ecological health and management, municipal use, wetland vegetation, and nutrients and other processes.

(2) No. The operation and control of stormwater and sewage networks in our cities is the responsibility of local government authorities, urban sewage and water authorities in the State and Territories under various administrative arrangements established by State and Territory Governments. The Urban Water Research Association of Australia, a part of the Water Services Association of Australia, is supported by the urban water authorities to conduct industry funded research into water issues for both metropolitan and non-metropolitan urban areas in Australia. Two projects:
assessment of storm flows in sewage systems; and

urban stormwater management in integrated catchment management, are being funded at a cost of $270 000. The latter project is being conducted in cooperation with the CSIRO Division of Water Resources.
(3) No, See answer to question 1.

(4) No. I understand that a research project by the CSIRO Division of Chemicals and Polymers for the adoption of the SIROFLOC technology to the treatment of sewer overflows commenced in January 1994. Expenditure for this project over two years is estimated to be $388 000. While good contacts have been established by CSIRO with both the Sydney and Melbourne Water Corporations, to attract interest in this work, a number of impediments to large scale implementation of this technology have been identified:
These include:
the need to licence sewer overflows discharges thus providing the legal incentive to manage sewer overflows;
the lack of ownership of the stormwater problem, often contaminated with sewer overflows and the lack of coordinated planning or initiative to solve the problems; and

the tendency of water engineers to consider civil engineering solutions (pipes in the ground) based on their lack of information of possible process engineering solutions (simple high rate treatment).

While some progress has been made to overcome these impediments, unless they are resolved and necessary resources are allocated by those responsible for these systems, then it is unlikely that a large scale demonstration project of sewer overflow treatment will eventuate from the work by CSIRO.

(5) No. The EPA prepared a discussion paper `Urban Stormwater, a resource too valuable to waste' based on the CSIRO report. Many of the 23 recommendations of the CSIRO report appear as general policy statements or areas of concern requiring further action at the local level. The discussion paper was designed to raise these issues with the broader community so they can help local governments to deal with these issues and work through potential solutions. The EPA also produced a Facts Sheet on Urban Stormwater as a means of raising the awareness of the community of the importance of this resource. The Facts Sheet suggests ways people may assist in reducing pollutant loads into the stormwater system.

Some recommendations from the CSIRO report are being taken up through the Commonwealth/State fora such as the Council of Australian Governments (COAG), the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC), the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ) and the Ministerial Council for Planning, Housing and Local Government.
COAG in February 1994 agreed to reforms for the efficient and sustainable use of our water resources. Over the next five years these will:
guide the introduction of consumption-based, full-cost recovery pricing of water and ensure that major water infrastructure projects are both economically feasible and ecologically sustainable;
support the adoption of integrated catchment management approaches to water resource management;

provide guidance for water allocations or entitlements, and institutional arrangements to allow trading in water entitlements so water is used to maximum benefit, within social and ecological constraints;
guide future water allocations for the environment, based on the best scientific information, to maintain or restore viability of river and groundwater systems, and
support institutional reform for efficient and accountable roles of regulators and managers.

The development of the National Water Quality Management Strategy by ANZECC and ARMCANZ includes the preparation of Guidelines for Urban Stormwater Management which will provide a national framework to manage stormwater in an ecologically sustainable manner.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) When did the research effort to develop an ammunition store to replace the United States (US)-designed (M374) mortar round begin at the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) in South Australia.
(2) When will production of a DSTO-Australian Defence Industries (ADI) round occur.
(3) What is the maximum range of this round planned to be.
(4) What research and development costs have been expended in this development to date.
(5) What enhancements over existing ammunition, for example the British L36A2 round, were envisaged.
(6) What enhancements have been achieved.
(7) What costs have been incurred to produce a round that was designed more than 20 years ago and in production 15 years ago.
(8) Has DSTO been able to duplicate this design successfully.

(9) Was a cost-effectiveness study done on the relative benefits of spending many years of DSTO research effort to essentially copy existing ammunition, versus licensing that design, as is or was done with the current US-designed store for the Australian Defence Force (ADF); if so, what was the result of the cost-effectiveness study.
(10) Is the range of the ADI mortar round reported in `Jane's', that is 6,500m, theoretically obtainable from the ADF's mortar tube under service rather than proof conditions.
(11) Has this design been plagiarised; if so, has there been any response from the British designers to their design being plagiarised.
(12) Has the DSTO encountered any copyright or patent problems in this regard.
(13) How did the problems with the improved mortar projectile design become manifest.

(14) With reference to the fact that the DSTO Research News states, as a tail-piece, that the new round will likely be substantially less costly to produce that the US-designed store, therefore are these cost reductions due to the new design by DSTO or are they due to production initiatives by ADI.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) DSTO commenced work in mid-1984, providing aerodynamic, propulsion and warhead effect advice to the designers, Engineering Development Establishment (EDE—since renamed Army Technology and Engineering Agency) and the then Defence Munitions Factories under the Office of Defence Production (now ADI). In 1988, the development of the improved round became known as Project IMP (Improved Mortar Projectile), and was managed by the Army and the Office of Defence Production.
(2) A decision to enter production is a commercial decision for ADI.
(3) The maximum range of this round is expected to be 5,800m to 6,000m, subject to the propellant pressure not exceeding the mortar barrel pressure limit.
(4) The total cost incurred by DSTO was about $1 million.
(5) The envisaged enhancements were reduced manufacturing cost, increased lethality, increased range, and local production.
(6) Increased range and lethality were achieved during the development phase.
(7) The design is significantly different from the UK L36A2 or other overseas extended-range 81mm mortar rounds. As indicated in the response to part (2), no round has been produced to date.
(8) Refer to response to part (7).

(9) The UK L36A2 was assessed by EDE in 1987 and, in light of the significant costs and changes required to purchase the UK design and adapt it for Australian manufacture, the Army decided to proceed with an Australian design.

(10) Ranges to 6,400m were reached in trials, but the blast overpressure was greater than the requirement. The maximum range of the production rounds will depend on the propellant selected and the barrel pressure limit and is expected to be less than 6,000m.
(11) No, the design is significantly different from the British design.
(13) During the pre-production phase, problems were experienced in meeting the specification for the quality of the cast mortar body.

(14) The design was commenced with low production costs as the primary goal, and the factories were involved during the design and development phases. In the event, the expected production cost reductions were assessed as not achievable due to problems with the cast mortar body. Any current information pertaining to production costs is a commercial matter for ADI.
